Six years ago, the grey philosopher told me,
“I have chiseled you, finalizing, hardening your stone.”
His philosophical theories weren’t the explanations I needed
Stern with authority,
“This is the way you’ll be.”
The beats of his chisel were off
The pose was too flashy
The pedestal felt too artificial
The light would never reach me
I was shadowed by his machines
Yet tourists were still urgent to visit me
With all their cinematography
With all their clicking and their beeps
I confused their flashes with light
I am the clay sculpture that chose to go on a walk
Distracted through the marvelous city at night, even through the mini-hurricanes
My left foot got stuck in a pothole, deteriorating by harmless water
My mouth was sealed shut
No one could hear my muffled cries
My weight was holding me in place
I did what I could only do
Let the vehicles and buses run, speed all over me
Let the harmless water disintegrate, taking me away
I am the clay sculpture that chose to go on a walk
Then the economy crashed, and so did the population
The city began to moss overall stone, including me
I thought I was forgotten, resting in piece
But a man saw that there was a chance of beauty in this city
He noticed that my stone was a lighter shade than the road
Behind him was his angelic family
His little girl picked up the tiny pieces, saying,
“Papa, these speckles twinkle to me.”
He opened his pouch, strapped on his shoulder, weaponless
With her hand placing the stone inside as if it was more valuable than the platinum necklace they refused to take
I am the clay sculpture that chose to go on a walk
He warned me what his process would consist of
He would melt me back to the lavish clay, I once was
Before my operation took place
He carved me a mouth and gave me medicine,
I didn’t feel the burning pain of the aggressive heat
Everything is now on beat
As he placed me in the furnace and closed the cage
Finally melting in place
Becoming relaxed
Conformable with no malice engraved
I feel free from the plinths from all those garage sales
He took me out on the furnace, the walls of his house felt even warmer
To the organic laboratory, he gave his next and final step
With a few words, feeling like an orchestral piece,
“How do you want to be perceived?”
Vulnerable, a painting in the shower, I spoke for myself –

“With all the imperfections like before, but with color and texture. Make me feel as if I am one of those children. Erasing all logic, structure, from the rocks I was born. Chisel me with your precise hands and guide me like the churn, stirring the milk, cutting the butter, all with a hot knife. Telling me your correct definitions of the love, passion, and the hardships of life. Give me a journey, keep me always moving on my feet. Never make me still, always keep me thinking. Create the most complex puzzle, and give me the chance… to piece it to together... to allow me to finally taste what it’s like to breathe”
He began to cloud his visions
I was afraid of water until the pellets fell on me
He began to work with everything he knew
I was afraid of his efficiency until I looked down at the pond
Telling me who you are is great.
There is no need to change.
All you all need is a splash of color.
A sense of feeling.
Blissful, that’s simply it

“Your imperfection in your stone is nothing to fear. Display it with dignity, let your fruition of strangers become guidelines if they shall come near. Cloth the accidents you love that you must keep to yourself. If you occur curious investigations, blind them away with the new color I have granted you – Silvenom. This permits you to have a coat of fabricated poison if anyone every scorns at your decisions. This shield of color wouldn’t send cobras to poison their prey. It would send an affable secret auditory message in their ears, whispering with selfless authority. Now go, find what makes you feel that you’re the weightless stone you really are.”
"How shall I repay you?”
“With the remembrance of me.”
I am the clay sculpture that chose to go on a walk.
I am the clay sculpture that is now accented with florescent rainbow stone.

Kale made the “Dirty Dozen.” Now what?

When Kale made the dirty dozen list for pesticide residues this March, it served as another reminder for me about the importance of either growing my own fruits and vegetables or opting to buy locally grown organic produce. In case you are not familiar, the “Dirty Dozen” is a listing of the top 12 or so fruits and vegetables that have the highest amount of pesticide residue left behind on the produce after washing and peeling. The list is released annually by the Environmental Working Group, and their analysis is drawn from data provided by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA). Kale is the number three most contaminated produce item behind Strawberries and Spinach.

I should begin by explaining that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) sets standards for the acceptable amount of residue that can be left behind on produce. On a pesticide label, you will find both the pest and plant the chemical can be used on along with the “Days to Harvest” designation. This represents the minimum number of days between the last pesticide application and when the produce can be harvested safely. If produce doesn’t meet the standards, it will be seized.

It has been almost 10 years since Kale has been tested for pesticide residues, and when the news hit, it went from being one of the most popular health foods to one of the most contaminated produce items. Exactly how contaminated is it? Over 92% of Kale samples had two or more pesticide residues left behind. The most heavily contaminated samples contained 18 different residues. The most frequently detected pesticide was Dacthal, and it was discovered on 60% of Kale samples. Most alarming to me was that in 1995, Dacthal was classified by the EPA as a possible human carcinogen and has been prohibited for use in Europe since 2009. Overall, 70% of the produce sold in the US has pesticide residues. The total number of residues detected on all tested produce is 225.

What does this mean for us? Your first line of defense is to grow your own produce whenever possible. Spinach and Kale can easily be grown. I have grown both in my garden and have never applied pesticides to them. When I do see insects on them, I pick them off by hand. The biggest challenge I have had with spinach is when the weather is too wet, so it is important to have well-drained soil or use raised beds. I don’t grow my own strawberries, but I do make sure that I buy ones that are organically grown.

This brings up the next question. What does organic mean? Some farmers consider their produce organically grown which means that they use organic practices but are not Certified Organic. Organic practices include using Integrated Pest Management which includes keeping pests at an acceptable level while using environmentally conscious techniques. Tactics include using biological techniques (like ladybugs to eat aphids), cultural techniques (like utilizing proper watering practices), and chemicals. All chemicals selected, including fertilizers, must be found on the OMRI list which is published by the Organic Materials Research Institute. The criteria for Certified Organic are more stringent and growers must follow the standards set forth by the USDA National Organic Program.

Whether you grow it yourself or buy organic when possible, it is important for you to be aware of both the most and least contaminated produce available to US consumers. This way, when you think you are eating healthy, you are!

In a world full of hair spraying, sloppy Joe eating, zombie-like inhabitants, the vegans, vegetarians, and gardeners end up coming across like Cousin It from The Addams Family. Thankfully there are some revolutionary thinkers such as Steiner and Pollen. They both employ the literary devices Logos, Pathos, and Ethos in an attempt to change the way the majority of the public sees the slaughter of over fifty-six billion animals a year and the 11.5 million square mile hole in the ozone layer.

For the close-minded souls of the world or the ‘I’ll believe it when I see it,’ types Logos plays a crucial role in convincing them that they should take a stand against the industry that slaughters billions of innocent creatures and be ashamed that the ozone is slowly crumbling into the land of misfit toys. Steiner brilliantly disgusts his readers by letting them know that almost everything includes animal products, “like wine and beer (isinglass, a kind of gelatin derived from fish bladders, is often used to [...] purify, these beverages), refined sugar (bone char is sometimes used to bleach it), or Band-Aids (animal products in the adhesive) [and last but not least] those little comfort strips on most razor blades contain animal fat.” (Steiner 772). As if this wasn't enough to have any meat-eater running for Whole Foods he also ruins any hope for organic living since, “chickens may be labeled free-range even if they've never been outside or seen a speck of daylight in their entire lives. And that Thanksgiving turkey? Even if it is raised ‘free-range,’ it still lives a life of pain and confinement that ends with the butcher's knife.” (Steiner 771). To top it all off he absolutely demolishes any traditional Thanksgiving dreams and replaces them with tofurky nightmares. At least Pollen provides a sense of optimism when he basically gives the end of the world eight more years. He stole his consensus from climate scientist, James Hansen, who informed the public that, “we have only ten years left to start cutting--not just slowing--the amount of carbon we’re emitting or face a ‘different planet.’ Hansen said this more than two years ago, however; two years have gone by, and nothing of consequence has been done. So: eight years left to go and a great deal left to do.” (Pollan 767). Pollan points out that the earth is worse off than it was a decade ago due to the, “Terrifying feedback [that threatens] to boost the rate of change exponentially, as the shift from White Ice to Blue Water in the Arctic absorbs more sunlight and warming soils [...] become more biologically active, causing them to release their vast stores of carbon into the air. Have you looked into the eyes of a climate scientist recently? They look really scared.” (Pollan 765).

Steiner and Pollan use Pathos, quite seamlessly, to pull at the heartstrings of those who cried in the movie theater during Frozen. Those who become teary-eyed when a cartoon snowman melts most likely, “denounce the ways in which [...] animals [are treated and] make impassioned calls for more ‘humanely’ raised meat. Many [...] soothe their consciences by purchasing only free-range fowl and eggs, blissfully ignorant that ‘free-range’ has very little if any practical significance.” (Steiner 771). The simple truth that free-range might not mean what it's advertising is enough to send any health fanatic into anaphylactic shock but Steiner kicks that poor soul while they are down when he tells them to, “think about that when [they are] picking out [that] free-range turkey, which has absolutely nothing to be thankful for on Thanksgiving. All it ever had was a short and miserable life, thanks to us intelligent, compassionate humans.” (Steiner 773). While that health fanatic is heaving on the floor Pollen takes the opportunity to discuss climate change, “linking our everyday acts to their real-world consequences, [and how it has become] easy for [him] to overlook the coal-fired power plant that is lighting [his computer] screen, or the mountaintop in Kentucky that had to be destroyed to provide the coal to that plant, or the streams running crimson with heavy metals as a result.” (Pollan 766). Even though climate change is an unpleasant subject to discuss Pollan lightens it up while still maintaining its importance when he states that, “the single greatest lesson the garden teaches is that our relationship to the planet need not be zero-sum, and that as long as the sun still shines and people still can plan and plant, think and do, we can, if we bother to try, find ways to provide for ourselves without diminishing the world.” (Pollan 768).

Steiner and Pollen utilize Ethos to shake the average reader’s sense of morality so that they feel badly about something they did not pay any mind to originally which ultimately makes them feel even worse. Society has come a long way in terms of agribusiness and mass production which is all well and good except for the fact that civilization has become less civilized because “these uses of animals are so institutionalized, so normalized, in our society that it is difficult to find the critical distance needed to see them as the horrors that they are: so many forms of subjection, servitude, and [...] outright murder.” (Steiner 772). Steiner’s work sets an example for the rest of the carnivorous population and shakes their moral compass since, “strict ethical vegans, of which [Gary Steiner is] one, are customarily excoriated for equating our society’s treatment of animals with mass murder,” (Steiner 770). Morality is embedded in the very core of most humans. The power-hungry like to justify unjust activity to the rest of the public in order to glaze over real issues and, “to justify doing nothing, but perhaps the most insidious is that, whatever we do manage to do, it will be too little too late. Climate change is upon us, and it has arrived well ahead of schedule.” (Pollan 765). As the ice caps melt into nothingness some give funds to “environmental organizations while thoughtlessly squandering fossil-fuel in their everyday lives--the 1970s equivalence of people buying carbon offsets to atone for their Tahoes and Durangos.” (Pollan 766).

Thanks to Steiner and Pollens expert use of Logos, Pathos and Ethos, those vegans, vegetarians, and gardeners do not look so out of place anymore. There are acts in place for more humane treatment of animals and many green products at the supermarket that don't harm the ozone. The world, while dark and gloomy, seems to be heading in a positive direction. Although if humanity does only have eight years left that health fanatic should sink their teeth into a big machine considering that the treatment of animals won't matter if the inhabitants of the earth have nowhere to live.

children.text: Days when I walk through the woods are always enjoyable. I come across many things out there, from nature made to human-made. Depending on what time of year I stroll around, a scene of primal dreams and rivalries exist around me. In the fall you have the beginning of the end for many life forms. Such as many species of insects and plants, and as the leaves fall to the ground and pile upon one another. Creating this mass of lost plant appendages, who’s loss of purpose is instantaneously reincarnated to decay amongst each other and feed the saprobes of the forest.

For the circle of life is a great wheel. A great wheel which will always spin, no matter what. Death is a part of life, and although that seems like an oxymoron. It’s a coherent sentence with profound inclinations. Death attracts life, you’re darn tootin’ it does. Would you believe there are plants out there that make it seem like there’s death in its proximity to pollinate? The Corpse Flower is a very comprehensive example of this phenomenon.

The Corpse Flower (Amorphophallus titanum) also known as the “dead man’s flower” is a very rare and unique plant native to Indonesia. More specifically to the western Sumatra and western Java rainforests. It can grow to a massive 10 feet tall when it is in full glory of bloom. The corpse flower is technically many tiny flowers (also known as an inflorescence). These plants can live for several decades and they only bloom every 7-10 years. In the meantime, A tree-like structure protrudes from the plant sucking up the sun’s indefinite energy and stores it in its corm for the major blooming event ahead. This event only occurs for 24-48 hours at the most. During this time an incredible amount of energy is explosively released. “When a corpse flower blooms, the spadix heats up to temperatures of up to 98°F as the plant unleashes a stench akin to rotting flesh. "Those pulses of heat cause the air to rise, like a chimney effect," Ray Mims, a spokesperson for the U.S. Botanic Garden, explained to Washingtonian magazine. "It gets the stench up in the air" to attract pollinating dung beetles and carrion beetles, who are drawn to the scent of rotting flesh. (Fawcett ‘17).”

This incredible flailing of sexual desperation is the corpse plant’s only hope for pollination and in turn, future generations. This plant’s massive buildup for such an acute event only shows its pressing importance. The event is a crowd pleaser and is sure to pack a botanical garden whenever it takes place. I can almost bet somewhere, out there. There’s one, whether in nature or captivity, getting ready to bloom just in time for Halloween. It would only be fitting for such a spooky ominous thing to occur.

Crust For Two 9" Pies With Enough For Decoration and/or Fancy Edges:
Ingredients:
3 cups flour
1 tsp. salt
1 tsp. sugar
4 ¹/2 Tbs. Chilled Shortening
12 Tbs. Chilled Butter
1¹/2 Tbs. lemon juice
Ice cold filtered water
Time to do this now.
1. Combine flour, salt, sugar in a large bowl.
2. Cut in Shortening & butter until the stuff looks like coarse meal.

3. Drizzle the lemon juice in along with enough water to make it clump together as you are tossing it around the bowl with 2 forks or a mixer on low. Shape into 2 disks, roll, toss into pie dishes, Google some fancy edge techniques or mark edges around pie shells with a fork and chill for 30 minutes.
Cool? Yeah, not yet so...
While those two are chilling out let's talk about the stuff that goes inside all of that delightful flakiness.
Pie Filling Ingredients:
1 ¹/2 cups sugar
Pinch of salt
Scant Tbs. ground cinnamon
1 tsp. ground ginger
Pinch ground cloves
Pinch allspice
Pinch nutmeg
4 BIG eggs, beaten
28 to 30 oz. mashed pumpkin or use canned if you must
12 oz. evaporated milk or thick oat milk
¹/8 tsp. vanilla extract
Time to do this now.
1. Mix dry stuff in a bowl.
2. Mix wet stuff in another.
3. Add dry to wet.
4. Beat together well.
5. Pour into pie shells.
6. Insert into 425° preheated oven for 15 minutes.
7. Turn oven down to 350°
8. Bake between 45 - 60 minutes. Test near the center of the pie with a toothpick after 40 minutes now and then until it comes out clean.
9. Cool for an hour on the stovetop and then freeze for about 20 minutes or until you have the temperature you desire.
10. Serve 'em or fridge 'em after that. It's up to you, My Kiddies.
With love,

A Holiday Regift Guide
My gift to you this holiday season is the following advice:
Try not to try so hard this year.

All the gifts and goodies will always be available because that’s how the world works now. Anything you want when you want it, you can have it. What makes the holidays really special is the people, the feelings, the spirit of giving. The holidays aren’t about waiting in line and spending money, they're about good tidings, comfort, and joy.
Some suggestions:

Give the gift of time—wrap the football, soccer ball, the baseball mitts. It doesn’t matter if it’s a new mitt or the one from the garage or the shed. The gift isn’t the glove or the ball, it’s the experience of the catch or the kick.
Knowledge is a gift—teach something to someone close, if you can drive a manual transmission, pass that lesson on to a younger member of the family or someone that can't.

Room to grow is an underrated favorite—at some point in the season, let it be out with the old. Things no longer needed or wanted can be given somewhere. With a little research, a perfect recipient can be found.
Replace as needed—socks, gloves, underlayers, outerwear, if they’re worn beyond redemption, new is good. If you can manage with last year’s fashions, save the money.

Regift—doesn’t cost a dime to look through a closet. Maybe you bought yourself that book you thought you’d like on your birthday, but that didn’t pan out. But just last week you heard your friend raving about how they want to read it and liked the others by the author. Why not give your copy to them?
Regifting is lame when it’s done out of laziness. With some good cheer and thoughtful effort, though it can be a brilliant and highly thoughtful gesture.
How do you pull off a good regift?
1.) Last year’s gifts are taboo and off-limits: Try to fool the recipient. The longer forgotten, the newer it feels. If it’s in very good condition it's valid.
2.) Is it still current/relevant/useful? (Careful: if it's something that they use day to day, don’t hide it wrap it and give it back, that’s annoying, not thoughtful).

3.) Barter with a friend—in gift-giving, a closed-loop carries drawbacks, too small a loop and you’re thoughtlessly recycling old gifts, too big a loop and you’re bringing in excess. Discreetly open the loop. Ask to borrow from your friend a gift for your brother and it could be greatly appreciated.
4.) The element of surprise—is it there?
New for the sake of new is unsustainable. I wonder if that’s what’s making the holidays feel so lame. Make the holidays not-lame by taking it easy with the ones you love most.

Folklore and Fact of Fairy Ring

For centuries Fairy Ring has been a thing of wonder, curiosity, and impending death? According to the folklore that has been circling around the world, since some unsuspecting soul stumbled upon the phenomenon, Fairy Ring has been regarded as a very bad thing in cultures with copious amounts of cautionary tales. Luckily, over the years we have come to understand this interesting ring or arc of mushrooms and how it occurs naturally, not by supernatural means, so we think…
Fairy Rings are thought to be “The mythical mushroom portals of the supernatural,” (ancient-origins.net 2018). In French culture, it is referred to as
ronds de sorcières
which translates to witches’ circles and
Hexenringe

is German for witches’ rings. Fairy Ring is widely linked to witches since they, as well as fairies, are said to dance in circles customarily under the eerie glow of moonlight. Since “These rings would seemingly appear overnight, or travel from one location to another, with no clear rhyme or reason” (ancient-origins.net 2018) in a time when this soil altering fungal disease was quite misunderstood, it was perceived as nothing other than witchcraft or the workings of some supernatural entity. Dutch superstitions claim that a Fairy Ring is practically storage for the Devil’s milk churn “and any livestock that were to enter said circle would suffer the souring of their own milk,” (Garden College Magazine 2017). I guess, the Devil really takes his milk seriously. In Austria, specifically Tyrol, “folklore attributed fairy rings to the fiery tails of flying dragons; once a dragon had created such a circle, nothing but toadstools could grow there for seven years.” (Wikipedia 2018).

Almost all of the mythology surrounding Fairy Ring points to the conclusion that stepping inside is a danger to whoever decides to explore their peaked curiosity. They are said to be inhabited by fairies, elves, witches, dragons, and of course, we can’t forget the Devil’s milk churn. “Even though fairy rings were thought to be little realms where fairies dance and play, lore suggested that if a human interrupted the fun, the cost could be deadly serious.” (Garden College Magazine 2017). In certain parts of Europe, it is warned that entering a Fairy Ring may cost the explorer an eye. In accordance with countless “English and Celtic tales, any human who enters a fairy ring will be forced to dance with the creatures, unable to stop until they go mad or perish of exhaustion,” (Garden College Magazine 2017).

So as to avoid blindness, insanity, and death, if one had an unquenchable urge, the only way “According to The Encyclopedia of Superstitions, a Northumberland tradition states that in order to investigate a fairy ring, one must run around it nine times under the full moon. If one were to accidentally add a tenth circle, ‘evil would befall the runner,’” (Garden College Magazine 2017). The legend of Llewellyn and Rhys talks of how time may differ in the realm of the fairies as opposed to that of the human world. Therefore, if one was to escape the grips of the Fairy Ring they may very well expire from the shock. The dangers of crossing over into a Fairy Ring are presented in this traditional Scottish rhyme:
"He wha tills the fairies' green
Nae luck again shall hae:
And he wha spills the fairies' ring
Betide him want and wae.
For weirdless days and weary nights
Are his till his deein' day.
But he wha gaes by the fairy ring,
Nae dule nor pine shall see,
And he wha cleans the fairy ring
An easy death shall dee,”
(Chambers 324).

Nowadays, the only danger of Fairy Ring is not so much linked to sudden death of the humans that enter it but that of the greenery it infects via the spread of fungal spores. Even though signs of Fairy Ring show up on the surface, the real damage takes place under the surface “in the soil or thatch and [it grows] outward, like a patch of mold growing as an expanding circle on a piece of rotten fruit or old bread,” (K - State 2015). Fairy Ring could be described as a simple fungal spot but on a much larger scale. It is a common belief in Wales that beneath Fairy Ring hides villages where fairies dwell. It’s interesting that while little was known about this fungal disease it was still thought that it’s random sprouting had something to do with the ground underneath it. And now, “Science tells us that fairy rings– or patterns of certain types of mushrooms that grow in circular formations– are [a] naturally-occurring phenomenon that usually appear year after year on lawns, in fields, and in forests. Fairy rings occur when a mushroom spore falls in a favorable spot, grows a mycelium (the vegetative part of a fungus), and spreads out an underground network of fine, tubular threads called hyphae. Mushroom caps then appear at the edges of this network. The formations continue to expand outward, using up all the nutrients within them as they grow larger,” (Garden College Magazine 2017). The largest documented ring--in Belfort, France--has subsisted for seven hundred years and grown in excess nearly six hundred meters (about two thousand feet).

There are sixty different types of mushrooms that can develop into Fairy Ring, therefore, “The unpredictable nature of fairy ring and its destructive impact on turfgrass frustrate even the best golf course superintendents,” (Fairy Ring 101 Mike Fidanza, PH.D.). The dreadful symptoms of Fairy Ring consist of a ring or arc of mushrooms, dark green grass, or necrotic plantlife. The fungi that cause Fairy Ring “do not directly infect turfgrasses like other pathogens [...] but indirectly cause turf damage by disrupting the environment below the surface,” (Fairy Ring 101 Mike Fidanza, PH.D.). While the fungus breaks down the “organic matter, its mycelium and other substances coat the surfaces of sand and soil particles, contributing to the development of hydrophobicity or soil water repellency in the rootzone,” (Fairy Ring 101 Mike Fidanza, PH.D.). There are various fungicides used to treat Fairy Ring. At times some of these treatments “work, and sometimes they do not. What works to successfully manage fairy ring on one golf course may not work on another golf course, or even at a different location on the same golf course,” (Fairy Ring 101 Mike Fidanza, PH.D.).

Whether there are little fairies helping to decompose the organic matter and further the Fairy Ring disease or such is simply a myth to hide the real fact of the matter… the Devil’s milk churn… just kidding… it remains a pesky fungal conundrum for growers and the superstitious. With the science behind Fairy Ring there are still those who won’t dare to enter. Even Shakespeare wrote about it:

children.text: On May 29, 2019, a tornado warning was announced for parts of New Jersey. This was my first tornado warning.

We prepared our outdoor furniture for the worst of the conditions. Collected the loose items into storage. Secured them from becoming projectiles. We kept away from windows. Our house is a small one level with an attic, garage with a loft, and a basement crawlspace. The trap door to the crawlspace was lifted. We grabbed our valuables. I was laying on the sofa reading a library book when the news broke: “Tornado warning.” I didn’t believe it. This area isn’t tornado alley. Ridiculous or not, believing wasn’t a requirement for getting through it. It was unprecedented. A lot of our modern existence is unprecedented. Times change. Weather patterns change. The climate changes. I remember a reading I had done for a class I took on sustainability. In his book, Eaarth, Bill McKibben writes that the weather will become more extreme and less predictable. Harsher storms, animal migration, new conditions unseen before. The list includes, now, tornado chance in new jersey.

I thought if this is real I better get my stuff together. What do you value when you have a fistful of minutes to pack a bag and find shelter to ride out the storm. I thought of my library book. The late fee... I'd be buying them a new one if I lost it.

Not important in this particular situation but I snatched my wallet. Communication, my phone. Prescription meds? Check—sort of. I stuffed these into my black gym bag. Waterbottle. Not much good without water. I filled it. Sunglasses? Not immediately useful on a cloudy, rainy day. Maybe in the aftermath when the clouds part. I changed into clothes I trusted, proven to be outdoor pants for one. Dad was urging me to put on shoes. Socks. Extra socks. Extra clothes. I stuff a change of clothes into the bag.

We cooperate, help each other. Dad set up the footstool below so nobody took a bad step on the way down into the crawlspace. He has set up cardboard as padding to lay upon. Water bottles, bananas. His bag is small. Mine is larger. I’ve snatched my journal, a pen and paper are useful in an emergency situation. It’s not until I’m down in the basement that my thoughts return to my library book. Something to read is a morale boost no matter what it is. If the mind becomes warped or frayed, the body is of little help. In a wait and see situation, a book is an asset. If necessary a book can stoke a fire. I lay on my back listening. Thinking. Mom brought her crosswords and some water.

We settle in under the house. I lay thinking. If wind starts ripping through our home what happens to our stuff? We’ve made an art and science of storing our excess. Boxes of things: old toys, decorations, clothes, photo albums. These all in the attic. In the garage loft, camping gear—sleeping bags, external frame backpacks, bedrolls, cookware, portable stoves, skis, snow boots, shovels and such. Our garage is full. Our small house packed with stuff. Out of sight out of mind. Down below in our crawlspace where we wait out this impending doom is more stuff. More boxes, more old toys, umbrellas, beach chairs, my surfboard, DVDs, games. Everything imaginable.

With all this stuff packed above below and around us I wondered what came next. Would we literally be crushed under the weight of our stored goods? Our consumption, was this all about to blow away on the wind? I can only imagine the destructive potential of what was reported to come.

Minutes pass. We listen to the weather channel on our television in the living room, its volume high. Before an hour is through a new warning comes. Flash floods. I breathe a sigh of relief. Mom and dad climb back up into the house. It's over. As fast and abrupt as the threat emerged, it ends. No damage. A little leaking as the rain picks up.

Before seven we’re back in the kitchen making dinner and sitting around. As I look through my gym bag, I am listing what I had packed, what I forgot, and what I might need next time. The prescription meds I packed were well-intended but a low pill count would leave me wanting after a few days. We had a little extra stored. I forgive myself for the mistake because the situation didn’t come to pass where my mistake’s consequences were realized. A good rule of thumb: No harm, no foul. Do better next time. Survival is victory. That kind of thing.

Yes, my preparation in those clutch minutes was imperfect. At least in the city and suburbs, in civilization, a rescue squad eventually comes. Just a call away. But oh, wait, my cell phone battery was dead. Dad’s phone was working.

Weather events put into perspective the important things. They can inspire us to reorder our priorities, assess our values. If you’ve ever in your life done as I have that night, you asked yourself what matters most?

I also selected my flash drive of writing projects, because it is my livelihood. All else, the books, films, games, fun gadgets, these could blow away. I’d survive. Losing the manuscript I finished last week—190 pages of a book I intend to publish, this would be a painful loss. The only losses worse than that would be family and friends—people or limbs.
I reflect on the event with gratitude for the gut check and question of what I value. That night I read a book I’d forgotten about until this event. A falcon guide to wilderness survival.

Breaking Free: From Winter’s Hold

This winter I learned something about boredom. It not only relaxes but it is a chance to mentally and emotionally tidy up our mind and spirit. I write in praise of lessons I learned when I listened to the inner voice that spoke to me in those idle moments. I owe a debt of gratitude to that boredom. For I would not have written this.

Everything hurts when life becomes too easy. Just getting through the day becomes about psychological avoidance of mental and emotional discomfort. As is the case with everyone, I too do this. I say, “I’ve had my share…” of headaches and heartbreaks. These comprise the unpleasantness of our increasingly well-insulated world. A casual interest in new forms of entertainment becomes a relentless obsession with occupying our minds. We stimulate ourselves and become maniacal in our avoidance of boredom. This is our existence in an increasingly unnatural world. During the cold seasons, it is natural to hibernate and take shelter from the elements outside. But the cold is passing.

Hibernation is a choice. I did not do much hibernating last winter. I took shelter, yes. I warmed myself and occupied my mind. I fed and put on a little winter weight, just a layer of warmth nothing distinct or obvious. Just enough for comfort. I layered up for my regular run and stayed on the move as much as I could. My efforts must have worked well because I came away from winter with a chapped upper lip and little else to show for winter having come and gone. This gash will heal. As will this discontent within me. April has just begun. I feel winter’s hold still. Trying to slip its icy grip. There is little evidence of spring. The days are longer, the ground warmer, softer, too. The wind is less bracing every day. A freshness is in the air as I breathe in the cool morning. Birds venture out. The trees are bare. Some have sprouted buds. Winter’s colors are slow to fade. But spring colors seldom hurry to bloom.

My emotions are still thawing from winter’s chill. It is apparent. The hopeful, serene, and romantic feelings we associate with the season have not flooded my veins as of yet. I try not to worry. I believe that they will. They will come. But, my faith in the season of spring is not an idle desire. I believe in spring because I believe rebirth and renewal isn’t a feeling that comes to me. I feel I must go to it. I don’t believe in waiting for spring’s euphoria to find me. I prefer to actively seek it. My suggestion: no matter the weather, warm or cold, wet or dry, go out into it. Dress for it or don’t. Feeling it on your skin or bundle up against it. Live the rite of the season. It may be here now, but soon it will pass. What would you like to look back on having done this spring? Do that.

Every new beginning brings new uncertainties. Hibernation is over. Out into the world. Carnivore, herbivore, two legs or four. Predator or prey, the world is in bloom. How will you be reborn this spring? Will you follow the patterns of last year? Have you lost your edge? Do you worry about keeping it? Do you worry if you’re up to the challenges this season will bring?

Today it is cloudy, quiet, serene. The air is cool but not cold. Early spring is a time to reflect and wonder. We know what is to come. As you wake from the dreamlike snowfields of winter, take stock. Be honest. How well did you prepare for the season to come? How well did you weather the winter’s bitterness? The snapping cold is a challenge we’ve conquered once more. It will return. In the meantime, enjoy the warmth to come. The subtle, seductive, settling in of the gentler days.

There is promise in the air. Leave the artifice of your home or office for a while each day. It will be there when you return. Even if it is for an hour or two, commune with nature and with one another. If only in passing, seek out others. Let go of our differences in opinion and ideology, leave politics at home and enjoy this weather while it lasts. The dog days will come. The scorching heat of summer isn’t far off. As for me, I will continue walking my path.

This winter I learned something about boredom. It not only relaxes but it is a chance to mentally and emotionally tidy up our mind and spirit. I write in praise of lessons I learned when I listened to the inner voice that spoke to me in those idle moments.

children.text: H2O; otherwise known as water... is the backbone of life as we know it. It covers 71 percent of the Earth, makes up 60 percent of our bodies, and is being polluted at a rapid rate. Out of all of the water on Earth, only 2.5 percent of that is freshwater. On top of that, only around 1 percent of all freshwater is easily accessible for drinking. The rest is stuck in snowfields and glaciers.

At the rate we are polluting... by 2050, the demand for available drinking water will rise by a third. The agriculture sector is currently the largest consumer, and polluter of freshwater. Every rainfall; chemicals and pollutants wash away from our farms and fields, only to find themselves in rivers and aquifers.

Another huge factor in freshwater pollution is wastewater. While wastewater treatment facilities in the U.S. treat up to 34 billion gallons of contaminated water per day, the system is old and can be overwhelmed. Worldwide; up to 80 percent of wastewater is dumped without being treated.

While we can all do our part by recycling, taking shorter showers, and trying to minimize waste… we can only do so much. If real change is to happen… there has to be change not only on a cultural level but a systematic level as well. We can't allow corporations to pollute for the sake of economic growth. We can't allow our nation's aging and outdated sewage system to dump 850 million gallons of untreated wastewater back out into nature. What we can do... is speak out. Get involved. Sign a petition. Call your local politicians. Do everything and anything you can to preserve this beautiful, strange rock we live on. Life will always carry on. It's just a matter of if we will be there to experience it.

I often think of what the world will be like by the time our kids adopt this Earth. I like to hope that we right the wrongs of the past. I want to hope that the coming generations will have a prosperous environment for them to grow into. A clean one. A healthy one. One where Polar Bears and Emperor Penguins aren't just a topic in school, but a wonder still of this world. Unfortunately, some may already consider this unreasonable or think that we’re too far gone. Or maybe optimistically naive enough to believe that nature will sort itself out and that this is none of our concern. The thing is... science doesn't care about your opinion; only progress and statistics.

In early 2019, the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences put out a research article using evidence provided by satellite imagery, snowfall data, and ocean temperatures. The conclusion of said article is that East Antarctica is shrinking and is so far responsible for 20 percent of the continent’s ice loss. The reason why this is so worrying is because East Antarctica is thought to be one of the coldest places in the world, and has 10 times more ice than the western side of the continent. With average temperatures of -67 degrees Fahrenheit and the coldest coming in at a record-breaking -144 degrees Fahrenheit. One would naturally think that this place would be one of the last places affected by climate change, but the unfortunate reality is that with our oceans getting warmer… the ice shelves floating on top are degrading. When an ice shelf holding back massive glaciers melts, the odds of said glacier sliding into the sea rises exponentially.

What this would really mean for all of us non-antarctic creatures is dramatic increases in our sea level. The Totten glacier (the largest glacier in East Antarctica), contains “enough ice to raise sea levels by at least 11 feet”, according to N.A.S.A.’s Earth Science News Team. Said Glacier is also one of several areas in East Antarctica where ice loss is around 1,000 meters per year. The ice that falls off eventually melts into the ocean, thus raising our sea level. Coastal cities and towns will be at the most risk. Especially in poorer countries and communities. Imagine the potential loss of land and life. The thing is, this won’t happen in one cataclysmic swift move that will change everything. It will happen over decades and decades. If we as a nation, as a people, and as a world collectively do better... we can avoid some of the most disastrous effects of climate change and give humanity the future it needs.

The drop sets in slowly as the season's change. We take shelter. The breeze becomes bracing. We shudder, shiver, stuff our hands in pockets. Make quickly from car to confines of our destination. We duck and cover from the elements. Water solidifies in slick patches to slip us up as we hurry from point to point in our laborious routine. Our uncovered skin tingles and numbs. The white flakes accumulate, cover the ground under gray skies, leaves in their golden days drop from tree branches. Decay before our eyes in intervals of days.

Only we notice it in-between moments. Gradual change feels sudden when not vigilantly observed. Our absent-minded progress through days and our tunnel-like perception. The seasonal climate is only to be endured when we’re out in it.

Who balls up the white stuff anymore and launches it? The sting of connection. Accidental or not, we’ve tired of it. Pain is to be avoided at all costs. Who needs to shiver? Why bear tingle in our fingers or the snap against our cheeks in the merciless air of this wretched season? Why not hide, wait it out, and watch from a window?
Because...

To learn to love the shiver, the shudder up the spine and the white flakes that melt on contact with our layer covered bodies—that’s the challenge of the season. To turn our collars up, huddle in our jackets and hats as the air gets harsher, this is real freedom.

It’s been ages since we’ve had to go out in it, leave the cave and thrive for a day or longer, weather the winds that sap us of our energy and the calm air that gives us little encouragement other than to say ‘go back inside’. Somehow our ancestors did it. Those of us with heritage dating back to temperate latitudes, northern, polar climates. If our forebearers knew high mountains, they braved the rough journeys of miles through tough winds and hard ground crackling underfoot. At the end of these ancient days, they too, unbundled themselves as they took shelter. They, too, rested, recuperated, commiserated, and celebrated a day won, lost, or survived with a crackling fire. Gathered with kindred spirits, held tight to the fragile, resilient, beautiful body of a close companion.

Tongues of fire still stand as a symbol of strength, bonding and for empowerment and tenacity. For good reason: we require fire, real and metaphorical, to survive. Build your fire as large and bright as you need, this season by night so that come morning you can do as you must… and equally important, as you please because what is life worth if it’s spent always working?

Strength unutilized is wasted. Spend what you will on an adventure. Take a hike, get out of the cave into the wilds. Come back safe, recuperate, and grow strong again. This is the natural pattern of the season. The darkest, toughest ordeal lay further up the road. I hope to see you there. You have the means, use them.
This is the nature of comfort: to ready us for hard journeys toward new meaning, new discovery, and new friends, to help us on our way.
Autumn is a gentle animal compared to the beast that is winter. Stay warm and enjoy.

Wolfsbane: A deeper look into the legendary flower

Wolfsbane is a well-known plant in the fiction realm of television drama and fantasy books. However, if one hasn't studied botany or done some research, then you may not have realized that it also has been referred to as Monkshood or Aconite. Along with being the name of this wonderful magazine, it's also a strong, very deadly poison. In the fantasy realm, it's a powerful weapon against the forces of darkness or mixed in the alchemic process of potions or droughts to save or transform a person. Today, I'll be separating the facts and myths of Wolfsbane.

In the realm of Transylvania in the early 1900s, it was used as a form of protection against the infamous Dracula warding a young lady against his desire to visit her. He then used hypnosis on a nurse and after she awoke, placed the Wolfsbane in the hallway drawer, thereby allowing Dracula to enter Mina's room and spirit her away to his dungeon. However, vampires don't exist in this realm so we cannot fully explore if it truly can be used as a ward; but if one goes by more modern literature and films, it does not. Wolfsbane was said to be used as a catalyst during a full moon while blooming to cause a transformation into a wolf, shape-shifting into a spider due to use from a goddess or summon hounds to protect oneself when used as an offering. Unfortunately, none of these are compatible with the universe as we know it. Two final myths that I've found about the plant is that it was made by the guard of the underworld: Cerberus due to the frothing rabid mouths of the three-headed dog and that it's used in charms to create invisibility.

While it's been mentioned in fiction and folklore for being utilized as a poison, that actually isn't a fabled effect. While it may be used to cause discomfort or death in fiction, it is capable of more than just the two broad categories. Wolfsbane or Monkshood, are just general names for a vast amount of different species of Aconite. They've been used for poisoning arrows, spears, traps for wolves and potentially attempted to be used for poison bullets by the Nazis during WWII. Thus far, there are 116 different varieties of Wolfsbane and 7 hybrids known to mankind. The tubers and roots of Wolfsbane are toxic and if overdosed on them, death can be instant. They're powerful neuro and cardiotoxins, meaning that they can stop the heart, damage or destroy the nervous system and wreak havoc on the blood vessels.

Symptoms of low dose poisoning are vomiting, diarrhea and nausea. A moderate level of Wolfsbane poisoning also contains burning sensation, numbness of the face or mouth, burning sensation of the abdomen and tingling sensation throughout the body. For severe dosage levels, hypotension (low blood circulation) sinus bradycardia (low heart rate) and ventricular arrhythmia (irregular heartbeat: too fast and/or too slow) just for starters. Following or occurring during a severe dose is sweating, confusion, difficulty breathing, headache, and dizziness. Death from overdose is from the heart becoming paralyzed or cardiac arrhythmia (heart attack or heart eventually stopping).

One is able to live through the severe poisoning, however you have to be hospitalized and have your blood filtered through a machine with activated charcoal, atropine or other drugs to decrease the heart problems, cardiopulmonary bypass surgery (heart and lung vessel bypass) if the issue is too severe or the drugs administered had an adverse effect after saving one's life. One of Aconite's many branches has also been known to be used medicinally in traditional Chinese medicine (TCM), ancient Roman and Greece medicine, Ayurveda and some parts of Slovenia. So fellow readers, do not consume Wolfsbane, Monkshood or Aconite in any of its forms unless prescribed by a long-standing practitioner of ancient medicine in select countries in the northern hemisphere or in eastern Asia.

So while Wolfsbane may not end up being a plant that can transform you, ward and protect against the forces of darkness or be alchemically produced to make you invisible, it can certainly make your enemies extremely uncomfortable or even die a quick, painful death. If you decide to handle this plant, always wear gloves to avoid poisoning oneself. It may look cool because of how the flower petals rest to look like a lowered monk's hood, but it's definitely hazardous to one's well being. Stay safe and look, but don't touch.

Let’s talk about flying dinosaurs. Not birds, not pterosaurs (they’re not even dinosaurs) - but the true non-avian dinosaurs. This article will focus on exploring the theory of flying dinosaurs, and what might’ve been if that dastardly meteor hadn’t wiped them out 66 million years ago.
Archaeopteryx

Technically cheating here talking about what’s considered to be one of the “first birds”. Archaeopteryx was from a family of dinosaurs called the avialans, which includes birds and bird-like dinosaurs.

Archaeopteryx means “ancient wing”. It was about half-a-meter (20 inches) and weighed as much as a modern-day crow. A most unusual bird indeed; it had two large-feathered wings with three clawed fingers on each end, a beak full of sharp teeth; and a long, bony feathered tail. It lived in what is now southern Germany in a luscious, dense forest. At the time, most of Europe was a large archipelago similar to the islands in Oceania. Fossil finds in the Solnhofen formation have found it didn’t have to share it’s home with too many other dinosaurs - at least any large ones, like the chicken-sized Compsognathus. It did, however, share its trees and the skies with a dozen species of pterosaurs, including Anurognathus and Pterodactylus. But the question for today is: Did Archaeopteryx actually take to the skies?

There’s still much debate in the paleontology community on whether Archaeopteryx was officially a bird or a dinosaur; was it a bird-like dinosaur or a dinosaur-like bird. Regardless of your stance on this, no one can argue that Archaeopteryx was the evolutionary missing link between dinosaurs and birds. Period. I personally see Archaeopteryx as more bird than dinosaur. But the official question… could it fly? New research states that yes, it could fly. But not like any bird you see today and was thought to be one of the first avialans capable of powered, flapping flight.

Archaeopteryx had the proper shoulder placements, skeletal anatomy and enough potential to achieve torsional resistance - this allows a bird to keep flapping in flight for longer periods of time. All this indicated that it could indeed gain significant altitude in flight and stay aloft for short periods of time. It wasn’t quite capable of flying enormously long distances, but in the dense forest environment of the Late Jurassic that it called home, it likely didn’t need to. It likely had just enough capability to fly tree to tree or retreat upwards to a tree branch to escape potential predators. But it had certain unique properties that set it apart from any bird alive today. Its wings were big enough to allow lift and prevent stall. However, it didn’t flap its wings like a typical bird does.

In conclusion, bird or dinosaur (or both), Archaeopteryx could fly. Primitive as it may have been, this strange ancient reptile soared through the skies on its beautiful, albeit primitive, wings. In millions of years' time, its descendants would find their way and rule the skies as we see them today.

children.text: Let's Rumball!
6 ounces semisweet chocolate, chopped
1 cup sugar, divided
3 tablespoons raw agave nectar
1/2 cup rum (Orange juice can be used as an alternative)
10 ounces ground vanilla wafer cookies
1 cup finely chopped walnuts

Okay kiddies, this one is easy! Melt your chocolate in a large bowl over a simmering pot of water. Then add 1/2 cup of your sugar and all your agave to the bowl. Stir until all blended. Remove bowl from heat. Add in your rum. Toss in the cookies and walnuts and stir a bunch. Then put the remaining 1/2 cup sugar into a shallow dish. Grab some mixture and form into 1 inch balls with your hands and toss into the dish to coat with sugar. Repeat until all mixture is gone. Store in fridge overnight to heighten the flavors or consume immediately like the animals you are :)

Snow. What a beautiful thing. It blankets the earth with its fairytale sparkle.
Treetops dusted with Winter’s chill. Streams, rivers and lakes of cold glass. Grass twinkling with snowflakes… oh… never mind… that’s Typhula blight on your lawn.

Typhula blight, more commonly known as Gray Snow Mold, is a pesky plant disease normally plaguing turf grass and sometimes wheat. It lies dormant during the warm months of the year and creeps out during the cold and wet periods when chilling blankets of snow mask its gray circle patches of mycelium.

Grasses such as bentgrass, perennial ryegrass, and kentucky bluegrass are but a few of the most susceptible to Typhula blight. So... if you live in a climate that is particularly cold and wet you may want to stay away from planting any of the above grasses... unless you want Gray Snow Mold... to each their own.

children.text: Mythology in every form is some nonsensical horse hockey. Dog-headed gatekeepers, little girls in white, masked spirits, all of those have vastly different and often horrible correlations based on the pantheon of choice (I’m looking at you, Japan). One fan-favorite mythological plot device is poison. Since advanced formulas for slow-acting poisons weren’t in abundance back in the age of pointy-stick warfare, the gods liked to use the literal poop-your-pants poison plants. One such plant was the Queen of the Poisons, Wolfsbane (Aconitum napellus).

The great poets such as Homer and Ovid spoke many times of the great poison in their texts. One of the earliest mentions of its use is the tale of Medea using it to poison the great hero Theseus. The spidery seamstress Arachne may also attribute her transformation to the magical Wolfsbane Athena used on her in a fit of jealous rage. It’s easy to make the logical jump to why this flower might be used against hulking beasts such as wolves, or more interestingly, werewolves. Since my werewolf traps go disappointingly empty, I had to study the effects of Wolfsbane in other, more google flavored ways.

Aconite is a genus of over 250 species of flowering plants from the family Ranunculaceae (I can’t pronounce it either). Herbaceous, perennial, and native to the mountainous regions of the Northern Hemisphere, these often brightly colored, hood-shaped flowers look very tasty to your average toddler and contain enough poison to stop an army of toddlers. I’m exaggerating, but not by much.

The hardest hitting banes of wolf owe their effectiveness to an alkaloid toxin called aconitine. A ton of research has been done behind the chemical properties of this toxin and Wikipedia manages to keep me confused through most of it, but the most important things to worry about are pretty simple.

As a neurotoxin, this poison works it’s magic by attacking the bits of your brain that you don’t have to think about to keep working. Aconitine does this by causing sodium influxes and delaying polarization, leading to pleasant sensations such as but not limited to: numbness that leads to burning, ventricular arrhythmia, heart palpitations, difficulty breathing, wrestling with your regrets, dizziness, muscle spasms, nausea, vomiting, rapidly finding faith, diarrhea, and death. Countdown to messy death is directly proportional to the amount ingested/injected, but it's rare for a victim to survive more than six hours on a twenty-milliliter dose.

The toxic nature of this plant is powerful considering toxicity alone. When paired with anything to make it stick to metal or stone more effectively, it becomes a poison capable of felling any beast with the smallest wound. The hunters of ages past knew this well, granting it the title “Bane of the Wolf.” A haunting title for such a tasty looking flower.

children.text: This is a world in which we aren't able to take the next breath before a new problem arises. We're all so connected. Able to know everything that happens, as soon as it happens. For better or worse. As a species, we adapt. We learn. We accomplish things that we never thought we could. We are always on the go. Always moving. But how do we slow down? How do we decompress?

One answer is simple and very old. Ancient even. I'm talking about nature and the practice of surrounding yourself with natural beauty. To embrace every single detail. To open yourself up to the sensory overload that is spring. To observe, and truly appreciate all of the small, magnificent things we take for granted.

The vibrant life that has returned to the forest floor, the resurrection of tree-top canopies, and the deep green that comes with. The deep blue sky and the sorely missed warmth of the spring sun reminds us that winter is over. Just standing still and taking it all in, will fill you with a type of hope that replaces the depression. Reminding us how everything has a purpose and a place in this world. You can feel a difference in the air as well. An overwhelming sense of life. A reminder; no matter how cold and grey life seems sometimes, life and color will always come back.
As a species, we adapt. We learn. We accomplish things that we never thought we could. We are always on the go. Always moving. But how do we slow down? How do we decompress?

Existence is an abstract subject, we spend most of our time thinking in the bounds of the construct we’ve created, and so little time asking the questions that we have very little clues to even begin answering.

Everyone’s an idiot, but the smartest among us are the ones who are an idiot the least often. We hold these people in the highest regard, and we let them do the thinking for us most of the time. Is our biggest folly our own intellectual modesty? Is what makes us as the Homo sapiens species so great been lost along the way? We must as individuals and groups alike challenge ourselves every day to be at the very least above average, to heighten our level of universal awareness. Our comprehension of all things that exist, have existed and will exist. As we hurtle towards a new decade, we all need to stop and think about this moment with great sincerity and deep reflection. every new year, everyone has their resolutions whether they act upon them or not. Well, let's take it a step further and make new life resolutions.

May something with highly positive novaturient implications come your way, and if it’s a negative situation turn that negative into a positive. Here's the understatement of this decade and the upcoming one; life is short. It really is, and it can pass you by if you are not careful. To live a vivid lucid life you must appreciate all moments and actions large and small. Sometimes we wake up in the morning with an unsavory attitude, saying things like I “got” to do this or I “have” to do that. Be grateful that you GET to do it. From the inside looking out, there are many selfish moments and statements to be had. Once in a while try to have an out of body experience by being on the outside looking in at your life, and realize self can be a sad lonely place.

As the new decade approaches think of the good memories of the 2010s more-so then the bad, we measure time in seconds hours, days, weeks, months, and years; but we still can’t firmly hold time or the future to concrete appraisal. For the future is forever changing due to free will, the free will of all who inhabit this planet. It is your free will to have a good attitude, and it is your free will to work hard at something. It is your free will to have an idea, and yours to execute upon it.

Metaphysical talk aside, aren’t I suppose to chat about plants on here? So since we are at winters doorstep let’s talk about some great robust houseplants to have during this upcoming winter season. With less light during winter, it can be an issue with certain house plants, so I'd suggest a pet plant such as the Chinese evergreen or Aglaonema. “Aglaonema have beautiful lush large leaves, some with patterns. Surprisingly, they can take low light and maintain their color and grow,” says Barbara Pierson, nursery manager at White Flower Farm. But if you are keeping your plant in a dim room, she recommends paying close attention to how much you water, as there’s a higher risk of overwatering. Also, if the room doesn’t receive much natural light, you can supplement sunlight with artificial light by placing your aglaonema near a lamp. (Katie Holdefehr 18’).” It’s always at least slightly beneficial to have a houseplant or two around, just to take pride in taking care of a living thing is a plus, and perhaps the very small amount of air filtration by the plant is useful. Maybe adopting a little green fella this winter season will be in the cards for you.

Whether you want a houseplant or not isn’t really important in the grand scheme of things. So as the days tick closer to the new year/decade look to positive changes, notice the things you have and be grateful for them, carry on toward whatever goal you may hold dear, and remember the past can hold you back from moving forward so you must confront your past in order to transcend your personal issues. Over time this will vaccinate you to from the non-sense in life and make you beyond poised to be successful in whatever you wish.
Happy New Year everyone!

Common Name: St. Johnswort
Latin Name: Hypericum calycinum
Origin of Scientific Name / Etymology:

The latin word Hypericum translates to “above a picture” due to the fact that ancient cultures hung cuttings of St. Johnswort over pictures to ward off evil spirits and entities and calycinum refers to the portion of the corolla structure underneath the petals translating to “with a conspicuous calyx,”(North Creek Nurseries). Legend has it that early Christians, in the first century, named St. Johnswort after the idolized John the Baptist because the flowers bloom around June 24th which was the birthday of the Baptist. “The striking arrangement of its five yellow petals resembles a halo, and when picked exudes a crimson red liquid which was believed by some to symbolize the spilled blood of their beloved John. [...] Wort is simply an Old English word for a plant or an herb” (Dr. Christopher’s Herbal Legacy).
Product Made From Plant:

Of the family Hypericaceae, St. Johnswort is a medicinal plant. The flowers or whole herb can be made into tinctures, capsules, and oils for various ailments such as anxiety, depression, viral infections, burns, scrapes, bruises, nerve pain, and seasonal affective disorder (Prescription for Natural Cures). For topical use fresh buds and leaves can be made into oils or dried for capsules and infused in teas. Soak pureed leaves and flowers in olive oil for four to six weeks to make a St. Johnswort medicinal oil. St. John's wort should be processed in direct sunlight, unlike most herbal oils. In order to make a rub/salve for bruises, strains, sprains, etc “Strip the young leaves and flower buds from St. John's wort and place in a blender with enough olive oil to cover them. Puree and transfer to a clear glass jar. Leave in the sun for three to six weeks. Shake daily. When the oil becomes a beautiful maroon color, strain and bottle. Then add one-third its amount of pure vitamin E oil, available in health food stores and mail order catalogues. (For example, if you have 1 cup of pressed oil, add 1/3 cup vitamin E oil.)” (How Stuff Works).
History of St. Johnswort's Use:

Dating back to 400 B.C Hypericum has been used medicinally. In ancient Greek and Roman times the plant was used for snake/reptile bites, menstrual cramping, gastrointestinal distress, ulcers, depression or melancholy, superficial wounds, or sciatica (Dr. Christopher’s Herbal Legacy). “When an injury was sustained, the individual often felt some measure of anxiety or emotional upset. Upon administering an infusion (tea made from steaming the leaves and flowers) of St. John’s Wort orally or applying the infused oil directly to the wound, a calming or sedating effect was noticed” (Dr. Christopher’s Herbal Legacy). Writings from the 19th-century talk of St. Johnswort as treatment for melancholia or more commonly known today as depression. “Some of these reported medicinal actions of St. John’s Wort have now been scientifically verified by double-blind studies, only to prove what the ancients knew all along” (Dr. Christopher’s Herbal Legacy). Now it can be picked up at many health food stores in capsule form, teas, tinctures, and even bath products.

Argentinosaurus: The Argentine Lizard

In 1987, rancher Guillmero Heredia was on his sheep ranch in Argentina tending to his animals when he stumbled upon something. At first glance, it appeared to be petrified wood but what Guillmero really discovered was the leg of the largest terrestrial animal to ever walk the Earth: The Argentinosaurus huinculensis! Argentinosaurus was a sauropod which are the long-necked herbivorous dinosaurs belonging to the group known as titanosaurs. These titanosaurs were the only surviving group of sauropods in the Cretaceous period up until the Cretaceous-Paleogene Extinction event. While other titanosaur species got to incredible sizes, Argentinosaurus was by far the largest herbivorous dinosaur! In this Paleo-Profile, I will be covering this massive titanosaurs anatomy and physiology, its diet, ecosystem, and it’s relationship with predators in its environment!

When I say Argentinosaurus was the largest dinosaur I mean it is the largest dinosaur! When Argentinosaurus was alive it got from 98 to 115 feet in length, 24 feet tall, and had a weight of up to 110,000 to 220,000 pounds! That weight is the equivalent of 22 African Elephants stacked on top of each other! Due to its massive size and weight, studies suggest that it could only move at a top speed of 5 mph, which makes sense as it didn’t need to be fast since its size was a deterrent for most predators. When people think of long-necked dinosaurs, they typically imagine them with elephant-like skin similar to the Brachiosaurus in Jurassic Park, but they most likely had skin covered in small bumpy scales that protected them and helped retain water inside the body.

But being an animal at this size comes with a cost, it NEEDED a lot of food to survive and grow! It’s estimated that Argentinosaurus would have had to consume 1,873 lbs of food each day that’s about 22,487 lbs of food per year! But what kind of vegetation did it eat? Argentinosaurus most likely fed on Noeggerathiales which is now an extinct order of vascular plants and plants that are still around today like gymnosperms which include conifers, cycads, ginkgo, etc. All that food consumption is what allowed Argentinosaurus to reach its full size!

When Argentinosaurus walked the Earth 95 million years ago, it lived in an arid environment with wet seasons. Its environment was filled with a diverse ecosystem that contained fish, turtles, and crocodilians. Argentinosaurus lived alongside other sauropod species including another titanosaur; the Choconsaurus. It also lived alongside carnivorous theropods such as the Mapusaurus which potentially preyed on this massive titanosaur. In addition to animals, this ecosystem was filled with lush plant life. The plant life consisted of hornworts, conifers, ferns, selaginellales, and even angiosperms which are flowering plants.

Although being massive has its perks, it doesn’t always mean that you aren’t un-huntable. As I mentioned before when talking about this titanosaurs ecosystem, Mapusaurus was one of the few predators that would have been capable of taking down an Argentinosaurus. Mapusaurus was a large theropod from the Carcharodontosauridae family. It’s estimated to be roughly 33 feet in length, 10-12 feet in height and weighed about 6,613 pounds! This large predator had teeth capable of tearing the flesh of its prey. But even though this is a large carnivore a lone Mapusaurus would not be able to take down an Argentinosaurus by itself. Fossil evidence suggests that Mapusaurus hunted in packs that may have consisted of 3-4 individuals. So how would a pack of Mapusuaurus take down an Argentinosaurus? Well there are two plausible theories. One theory is that the Mapusaurus pack would bite the legs and other parts of the body. By doing this it would be able to bleed out the titanosaur until it collapsed of blood loss. But that method would have taken too long and would have resulted in a longer wait for a meal. This next theory is more efficient and would have allowed for a quick meal. Instead of killing the Argentinosaurus, the Mapusaurus may have instead ripped off pieces of flesh and eaten those. This method would have allowed Mapusaurus to get in fast and leave fast, reducing the risk of injury. But even though Argentinosaurus was a large and slow animal it was more than capable of defending itself. Its long tail could have been used to hit predators and would have severely injured them, it may also have been capable of rearing up on its hind legs and stomping back down on the predator killing it instantly. As a herbivore Argentinosaurus would have lived in herds that would have deterred any predators from attacking if the herd was large.

Ever since it was discovered, Argentinosaurus has been a huge focus in the modern studies of maximum dinosaur sizes. It’s large massive size changed the way we understand how large an animal can get, we now know there are multiple determining factors that influence size from genetics, environment, and even diet. This 115 feet long sauropod successfully dominated the remainder of the Cretaceous period up until the inevitable extinction event that wiped out all the non-avian dinosaurs. Although massive it was still susceptible to predation but was still able to fight back. Until the next great discovery, Argentinosaurus is truly the largest land animal to ever have existed.

Movies are another gift idea people do, Marvel and Starwars products feed Disney’s profits. How many of us go to Walmart? Something exploitative infected the holiday season because as my brother aptly said, shopping anywhere, “feels like walking through a web browser.”

The ritual is set, we buy stuff, wrap it up, gift it, unwrap it. Decorating the tree feels like the chore that it is when the season is purged of sentiment. Without the spirit of giving, the holidays are reduced to the cost of doing business. Beginning with Black Friday, ending after the holidays and around the end of December.

Maybe you get together with family if it's not too politically awkward, maybe you see the light displays, some other festivities. Or maybe your family is like mine, too busy to really celebrate like we used to. When is the last time, anyone went caroling for Figgie pudding? It feels like a long-dead pastime to me.

If necessity is the mother of invention, then excess is the angel of death complete with a scythe. Necessity is the deciding factor this year in my holiday shopping. If they need it new, they get it new. Only if it needs to be new, is it bought at full retail or some so-called discount. Same with asking for stuff. What do I need? Sadly, not much. Shelf space would be great. A day off from school, work, responsibilities.

Here’s a call to action you can consider. Spend less, give the things that can’t be bought, time is among the most appreciated gifts. Don’t be ashamed to regift, either. And for once in your life, try this: if someone doesn’t ask for anything special, then maybe there is nothing more you can buy that will make their holiday more cheerful. How about a fruit basket? Food is a welcome gift, and eventually either wastes or is eaten. Rewrap something already in the house, ideally something half-forgotten but deeply cherished. Get creative this season.

Once again Christmas time is hastily approaching us and I'm sure that a lot of people are deciding if they want a real tree or if they should get a fake tree instead. What type of tree should we get? How big can we get without breaking the house or the bank? Should we have one inside or outside? What should we do with it once Christmas is done? These are common questions for both fake and real tree consumer/future customers. Let's look over the positives and negatives of both types.

Real trees are nice to have, the fresh scent permeating throughout the homestead of pine, fir and/or sawdust if it's cut freshly enough. Depending on if one is really dedicated to having a massive tree in their yard for the holidays or just a simple one inside the house, the effects can be of major impact on them environmentally. If one goes for a fully grown tree, they could have enough oxygen for a family of four. However, the fuel transportation costs may be exceptional, because Oregon is a mass producer of Christmas trees, exporting worldwide. Real trees also include personal danger if cut down personally.

That then leads to more detailed issues, such as keeping the house clean from the needles as the tree slowly dies from malnutrition, having it continuously being watered, any allergies stemming from the particular type of tree, ensuring that there aren't any animals or insects inhabiting the tree, and the eventual disposal of the tree once it's fully dead. To avoid unwanted creatures, Christmas tree farmers use pesticides, insecticides, and herbicides which can lead to cancer or birth defects if enough is absorbed into the skin. Ideally, these are already washed away from the initial spraying but trace amounts can remain and what is washed away does have major influences in nature. If one keeps their tree inside and has pets, then they have to worry about if the water or the needles are consumed, which can be harmful to one's little family members such as ruptured intestines, choking or poisoning from lingering chemicals.

With fake Christmas trees, a lot of the worries and tribulations involving the hunt for the "perfect" tree are nonexistent because you've already bought a factory perfect replica. Now it's really only a matter of setting it up. Fake trees are a commonly plastic based material called PVC. PVC can contain lead, cadmium or tin as stabilizers. Lead poisoning can cause seizures, lower IQ scores, autism, irreversible brain and nervous system damage, violent behavior, just for starters. If it's near a heat source, the chemical dangers of it melting or burning are a major health concern. They release gases over time and as they slowly deteriorate. After 9 years, the effects are greater due to the metals deteriorating as well. If one were to include small electronics with their generated heat (i.e., Christmas lights) creating more wear and tear, then the deterioration increases exponentially. PVC and lead chemicals also increase the possibility of infertility and decreased testosterone. There's also the issue of flame retardant chemicals being consumed via breathing or skin contact from the dust around the fake tree.

So, what can one do if these both seem like overwhelming decisions and don't sound like good choices? There are non-toxic fake trees out there, but the price will be steeper because it's made of a special set of materials. For real trees, wash it off to get the outer layers of chemicals off and cover the bowl in which the water sits while it's indoors. To prevent or minimize the gasses released from the fake or real trees, put them outside where it's highly ventilated. Another alternative that my family and I personally have used since we stopped using both real and fake trees is a ceramic one. It's small, needs no maintenance, no time used decorating or wiring because it's painted on and much more portable and mobile in comparison to either one of the others. One will ultimately choose whatever they want in the end, however, they should be more aware of what they're buying or at least conscious of what is cornerstone of Christmas decor.
