children.text: White pine needle tea has been used by the ancients for hundreds, if not, thousands of years and maybe many more... it was used by the native Americans for its healing properties. In fact, they introduced it to early settlers as a cure for sickness one being scurvy, which is caused by a lack of vitamin C.

White pine needle tea is great for colds, chest congestion, and upper respiratory illnesses, though it is also rumored to help with many other ailments as well, such as cleaning and rebuilding the lungs, and more. I encourage everyone to do your own search on the web to confirm and find out more. It is packed with antioxidants, vitamin C and vitamin A. Per serving it is said to have four to five times more vitamin C than oranges.

Fortunately, pine trees are found in abundance all over the US so it is an easy and free tea you can make at home. I happen to find them all around where I live so it's very easy to make this tea all year round, even in the midst of the winter.
*1/2 cup of pine needles, young green pine needles are best.
*1.5 pints of water
*Bring water to boil in a stainless steel pan (do not use aluminum)
*Add the pine needles, reduce heat to simmer for 20 minutes to overnight.
*Strain the needles and drink warm or cold

The tea should be red in color with a little oil floating on top. You can add honey or cinnamon if you like. It doesn't taste like pine, it has a very mild flavor. You can use almost any pine or fir tree (though the recipe may differ). Remember, some pine and fir trees are poisonous. Pour boiled water in a cup and do not boil needles in a sealed jar as this may release harmful turpentine. Do not drink pine needle tea when pregnant or if you are allergic to pine.

The skies do darken, the days grow short, and the winter winds howl in the treetops. This time of year, people seem to grow colder both in temperature and in spirit. Even with the holidays approaching, it can be tempting to huddle inside, bid your friends adieu until the spring thaw, and hibernate like a solitary woodland creature. But I propose a different, more communal tact.

There is a tradition that goes back centuries, even millennia, in the British Isles: that of the Wassail. The word itself comes from the Old English “was hal ”, attributed to the Anglo-Saxon greeting “wes du hel”, essentially meaning “be you hale”, or “be healthful/healthy.” Many have sung that old holiday carol:
“Here we come a-wassailing among the leaves so green!”

But not all consider precisely what Wassailing could mean. When I was younger I was under the impression that it was just some ancient synonym for caroling, when in fact the history of the wassail has a rich history as a communal drink in harvest ceremonies or around the dinner table.

Wassail is a traditional hot mulled punch typically made of mead or wine into which (originally) roasted crab apples were tossed and joyously burst to be drunk on Lammas Day, a pagan holiday which persisted into Shakespeare’s time. Later it became a mulled cider, with nutmeg, cinnamon, clove, and ginger, topped with slices of toast to be used as sops. Modern recipes typically start with wine, fruit juice, or mulled ale, sometimes with sherry, ale, or brandy added. Sometimes large baked apples and oranges studded with cloves are added to the mix, and occasionally whipped eggs can be tempered into the mix. The recipes vary widely over the many centuries that the Wassailing tradition has been observed, but the common theme among all of them is that they are made to be shared and drunk from a large communal bowl.

I am not endorsing drinking for the sake of drinking, not by any means. What I propose is this: find the largest bowl in your house, whip up a communal drink to be placed in said bowl (whether it has alcohol or not is entirely up to you, plenty of non-alcoholic punch recipes can be found), and invite your closest friends and loved ones to gather around and share in the revelry. The Wassail is not just the drink, but the act of drinking it. To come together around the hearth, look one another in the eye, and toast to friendship and good fortune in the coming year. The ceremony of it will not only warm your body but your spirit as well.

children.text: Slow and Small Solutions of a Culture of Permanence

I’ve often wondered. All this panicked, alarmist, bleak assessing of our environmental upheaval. There are big problems afoot. It’s easy to lose sight of what’s important. Easy to quit and say, "Why even bother caring about the environment?"

According to Harvey Blatt’s (2011) book America’s Environmental Report Card: Are we Making The Grade? “Living Creatures are adaptable…Those in the business community may justifiably be concerned. But for those interested only in the survival of life forms on planet Earth, there is nothing to worry about.” (p 247)

According to Bill McKibben’s (2008) book, Eaarth, it is written similarly, “The way our economy works at present, any cessation of growth equals misery…but we can’t grow…we’re on an uphill planet, so we’d better change. (p 97) Fredrick Bastiat states in Dean Russell’s (2007) translation of Bastiat’s The Law, “…we must wait until we have learned by experience—perhaps cruel experience—to trust in the state a little less and in mankind a little more.” (p 67)

Enter individual number 45, Donald J. Trump. His ‘clean coal’ conjectures are no doubt tempting offers to those business leaders who are currently in power over our sources of energy. But according to Factcheck.org:

“‘clean coal’ refers to technologies deployed at power plants that make coal cleaner to burn, not to the fuel itself. Modern definitions require cuts in carbon dioxide emissions, and the only way to do that in a substantial way is through carbon capture. Just two coal power plants in the world use the technique, and it makes up less than 0.1 percent of American coal-fired capacity.” (McDonald, 2018)
Here's a fun fact brought to you by Endcoal.org:

“Coal is only considered cheap because coal plants do not have to pay for the full social and environmental costs of coal burning on people’s health, the natural environment, and our climate. These costs, known as “externalities”, would double or triple the price of electricity from coal according to a Harvard University study, making renewables much cheaper. In China, mortality from air pollution is now valued at 10% of GDP. A 2015 IMF assessment put global fossil fuel subsidies at $5.3 trillion annually, which includes the costs of managing the environmental and health impacts of coal.” (Coal Myths, Endcoal.org)

children.text: What of green jobs? According to Eugene Kiely’s (2019) Factcheck.org post:

“…Washington Gov. Jay Inslee has claimed that the top two fastest-growing jobs in the United States are in clean energy: solar photovoltaic installers and wind turbine technicians. That’s not the case — at least not yet.” They are, he writes, projected to be “the fastest growing by 2026.” (Kiely 2019)

There is enough bad news to make anyone listening to it want to shrink from reality or get away and move someplace else. Burning fuel to run from danger or toward a good cause like planting trees or to travel hundreds of miles cleaning up garbage. Isn’t it a zero-sum game? Who can know the score?

Survival expert Les Stroud, suggests in his (2008) book, Survive!: Essential Skills and Tactics, to Get You Out of Anywhere—Alive: “You’re stranded, stuck, likely alone in a place that a few moments ago was a wonderland of adventure but now has become a living nightmare. Your next move is crucial to your survival.” Survival, he writes, is about more than knowledge and skill, it “requires clear headed thinking, mental toughness and a positive attitude. It requires a never yielding will to live.” (p 39) So here we are on earth, a short while ago we caught on to the fact that our world was turning from “wonderland of adventure to a living nightmare.” Our “next move is crucial.” Tornado warnings in places not previously prone to them, sea levels rising; maybe one day whole cities get washed away when the coastlines are redrawn. Economic trouble, political turmoil. It’s time to focus and get to work. What is the ordinary citizen to do? When ‘clean coal’ and Trump are still at odds with efforts to update the nation's expansive power grids and the replacement jobs in green energy taking their time, it’s a period of limbo for the average person. There must be something we can do, no?

Beyond the prevalent existential fear that is behind all awareness of our climate problem, our saving grace will grow not from regret or pessimism but out of an attitude of proactive, small scale, self-reliance. This is the world of permaculture.
The world we are in is predicated on a frictionless relationship with abstract and immaterial and in some cases trivial ideas. We had to endure it to get there to the world of tomorrow.

Imagine if you will this world of tomorrow. It is not that of automation, but it is one of autonomy, personal responsibility, and a frictionless relationship with nature. Welcome to the Great Transition. At the heart of this transition is a “’lifestyle designed for permanence’ [that embraces] ‘the evolution of small-scale technology, relatively nonviolent technology, technology with a human face.’” (E.F. Schumacher qtd in McKibben,2008, 93)

If not for the set of coincidences that included a college English 102 research essay, a book called Stealing Fire and a rope dart performer/permaculture enthusiast known as Flow Mayhem, I wouldn’t have stumbled into my current and minimal understanding of what Permaculture is. Deeper exploration of the concept brought me to permacultureprinciples.com. Because there is more content than I can effectively sum up in this article I encourage you to jump down this rabbit hole with me.

Permaculture was originated by David Holmgren and Rob Hopkins, co-originator of the Transition Network. There is more actionable information than can be summed up in a single article in this magazine so we encourage you to check out these sites and see for yourself what small and slow solutions you can integrate into your own lifestyle at:

Amazon: normally one would think of the web-wide shopping center, however, that is not what is going to be delved into today. The Amazon rainforest is located in South America. Nearly two thirds of the Amazon is rooted in Brazil and is a part of 8 other countries as well. The Amazon rainforest is the largest representation of rainforests in the world, coming in at around over half. The Amazon rainforest is 55 million years old and is over 2 million miles squared. There are hundreds of billions of trees (roughly 390 billion in total) with a whopping 16 thousand different varieties of tree species or genus.

Another keynote that one thinks of is the Amazon river if one had ever played the old pc game: The Amazon Trail. There are 41 hundred miles of river flowing in the rainforest. Within these vast miles of river and jungle, there are millions of different types of species that we have yet to discover. Of the ones that we have, there are 40 thousand different species of plants, over 370 types of reptiles and 3 thousand varieties of fish and two and a half million types of insects. For the human side of living there, there are over 30 million people and 350 different ethnic groups that thrive and live off of and rely on the natural abundances for food, water, shelter, medicines, and daily livelihood.

This summer, the Amazon was huge news to people around the globe due to the unnaturally high amounts of fires running rampant in the rainforest. There was a record-breaking amount of fires in Brazil alone, nearly 73 thousand separate fires and over half were in the Amazon region alone. That is a massive 84% increase compared to last year in 2018 (roughly 40 thousand). However, it is sadly not the first time that the rainforest has gone up in flames. In the late 90s and early 2000s, there were 50 to 74 thousand fires in the Brazilian region. These areas of ignition were influenced by large amounts of deforestation. Deforestation has been a plaguing issue from the 1960s when farmers tried to stake a claim for themselves and resorted to the slash and burn method of increasing their plot due to limited time of fertility.

Later in the 1970s, the Trans-Amazonian highway was attempted to being constructed, furthering the destruction of the biome. It has since been halted, limiting the environmental devastation. In the early 1990s to early 2000s, the total loss of forest had risen from 160 thousand to 227 thousand square miles, 91% of which was used for livestock pasture. Due to the farmer's needs, they've justified building highways in the rainforest; two of them have been opened and led to more deforestation and increased settlement. Stemming from the settlements, oil reservoirs have been found in the 1970s, which caused a boom in drilling and another one in the early 2000s. The effects of deforestation have been so drastic that it has been able to be seen with one's naked eye from space.

While the release of carbon from the destruction of the plants is a huge worry to the scientific community, what with it able to cause worldwide effects depending on how much is destroyed, the burning of the biomass from Africa is a boon for the growth of the forest. It along with the Sahara desert is a major contribution to the overall growth from the phosphorus deposits. These deposits are vital for the re-growth of the rainforest and are enough to replenish what was lost from the flooding and yearly rainfall. The rainforest itself is a huge role-player in keeping the ecosystem stable and intact for the southern continent and overall has world-wide effects of staving off global warming.

Aside from the Brazilian and American Governments advocating and lobbying for further industrial endeavors, the rest of the world stands by protecting the rainforest. In the coming years, drought will have an astronomical impact on the rainforest. It will be the tipping point of whether or not the Amazon rainforest will begin a descent into a savanna or continue to exist and slowly re-grow its splendor. Millions of different, unknown or undocumented species exist within this temperate biome and we've only just begun to scratch the surface. Only 1%, perhaps 2% of the species have been documented within the Amazon rainforest. If humanity as a whole can come to an understanding and delve into the scientific aspects, the boon will outgrow the temporary short-term drawback of investment. I believe that with keeping the rainforest safe, we as a species will thrive in the future, long after we readers have passed on; it's an investment for our future brethren.

children.text: The Palo Santo tree itself has been utilized this way for a very long time. children.text: Great Expectations: Last Year’s Spring

I had two cameras. One was a vintage piece of equipment—a Vitavar 220/Sl with a telephoto lens. I loaded it with 35mm 400xp black and white film. It made a distinctive click when I snapped the shutter. I took it with me on several outings into Pennsylvania. Twice to Ralph Stover State Park and once to a spot in Birdsboro. The other traveled in my backpack on the same outings. It was a compact Fuji Zoom Date that I picked up for $12 at an outdoor market. The thing technically still operates. Although I had previously snapped a full roll of Kodak film from the three outings no pictures were recovered from this camera. At some crucial point, the roll of film was light-exposed and effectively ruined. Suffice it to say, I’m saving up for a digital camera. There is no substitute for a good camera. The incident with the film reminded me that the best memories sometimes evade capture. Sometimes, I think back on them when I write.

Sitting with three friends watching the waning of a long April day at the crag in Ralph Stover where we climbed, we take pause at the view of the treetops, the snaking river, and that mysteriously solitary shack in the middle of the bare-branched woods. We slip through a hole in the fence and sit by the rock outcrop with a cooler of Bavarian beer. Our foursome is careful not to venture too close to the ultimate precipice. This hour of comradery is a priceless memory. This was last year.

If you worry about finding the time, plan ahead, coordinate, and adapt. Humans are adaptable creatures. I think it’s easy to forget how resilient we can be. In an increasingly digitized culture, we spring for the ready-made experience: the movies, games, television, and on-demand streaming—the shows, the videos, the distractions. It may seem they are hard to escape. I too fall into the sofa from time to time to recline and zone out. Nobody is immune, nobody is totally trapped. The cage though it may not be physical, it is all the more real. Break free. Stretch your comfort zone. Find a way to feel harmony with your world. I could go out there alone but what fun would that be?

The oppressive neuroticism of modern life cripples our human interaction by injecting urgency into situations that do not require it. Bloated algorithms inflate and warp reality. Though our technology improves, our nature remains the same, we are nomads, we are tribal, we are sociable, sentient, aware creatures. I think we are slowly realizing this planet we live on is our best friend. It makes possible so many adventures, experiences, and connections that would otherwise be lost. To take it for granted is to lose a part of our humanity. To take each other for granted is to lose outright.

No individual is an island. We thrive together. Spring is a time of romance and bonding as well. This kind of closeness is a journey. Learning about one another, feeling out the other’s sensibilities is an exciting opportunity for internal, spiritual, and intellectual growth. A friend encouraged me to try my hand at writing for this publication. I am grateful for the opportunity. I lean on friends for support. I haven’t always, but like the way the trees block the wind, we are better together than we are alone.

The planet is changing. If we are to survive, we must rise to every challenge nature provides. It is a time of change. Every time is a chance to evolve. Nature is clever, we must respect her intelligence. If we can set aside our hubris, then we stand a chance at getting through whatever comes next.

children.text: Last time we talked about Marvel characters with plant-based powers, so it’s only fair we spend some time on the “Distinguished Competition” as well. Like Marvel’s writers and artists, those working at DC Comics were incredibly imaginative when it came to the origins and powers of their creations. You may have heard of the Kryptonian who crash-landed in Kansas as a baby and grew up to become one of Earth’s most ardent defenders. I’m sure you’re also familiar with the Amazonian princess who was raised on an island of fierce female warriors. Let’s also not forget about the guy who mistook super-plastic formula for soda and wound up with the amazing ability to...bounce. Seriously though and no pun intended, somebody really dropped the ball when creating Bouncing Boy.

Like the Marvel heroes and villains we looked at in the previous column, only a couple of these characters are well known, while the others are what you might call deep cuts. The one major thing they have in common is their powers, which are all plant-based. Let’s dive into these DC characters who gain their impressive abilities from nature.
Swamp Thing

In the last column, we discussed Man-Thing and shockingly, rival publishers Marvel and DC created him and Swamp Thing at the same time! Well, technically Man-Thing debuted two months earlier. Although the characters were undeniably similar, there was never any legal action taken. This is likely because both creatures owe a debt to the Heap, who beat them both to the punch, appearing in Hillman Periodicals beginning in 1942.

Len Wein and Bernie Wrightson created Swamp Thing in 1971, and those original issues are excellent. However, it was the second volume of the series that really elevated both story and character when Alan Moore took over as writer. He stayed true to the comic’s horror roots, but also steeped the book in existential philosophy.

Alec Holland had once been a brilliant scientist who refused to sell his “bio-restorative formula”, leading to his lab being sabotaged by the people intent on acquiring it. Ravaged by those chemicals, Alec dove into a nearby swamp in a last-ditch effort to survive. It was then that Swamp Thing was born. Moore’s run on the book saw a major paradigm shift by dispelling the notion that the creature had ever been human to begin with. Swamp Thing was actually a plant who had only mistakenly believed himself to be a man due to his absorption of Holland’s memories and knowledge.

Composed of sentient vegetable matter, Swamp Thing is self-sustaining, has superhuman strength and has total mastery over all forms of plant life. He can both communicate with and control it. Swamp Thing is also capable of astral projection and possession. His powers of regeneration are seemingly infinite. He can alter his size and even create multiple copies of himself. Swamp Thing is a plant elemental who derives near unmatched abilities from the Green (the mystical realm that connects all botanical life) and is one of the most powerful heroes in the entire DC Universe. He’s also unequivocally awesome.
Poison Ivy

Created by Robert Kanigher and Sheldon Moldoff in 1966, Poison Ivy’s original look came from famed 1950s icon, Bettie Page. Pamela Lilian Isley was a young botanist whose future was looking bright until she became the “Vined Vixen”. Like most comic characters who’ve been around for decades, Ivy has had more than one origin story. The more recent background is that Dr. Isley studied botany under Dr. Jason Woodrue (more on him next) aka the Floronic Man. He not only romanced his young student, but experimented on her as well. Ivy survived but the toxins that transformed her also left her emotionally unstable.

Poison Ivy is one of the Dark Knight’s most powerful adversaries. She’s immune to all natural toxins and diseases, is super strong and emits pheromones in order to easily ensnare her prey. Depending on what you read, some writers have portrayed Ivy as more human than hybrid, while others have given her more in common with plants than people. For example, she doesn’t breathe oxygen and she needs sunlight to survive. Nature has always been very important to Ivy. In fact, she can quite literally feel its pain, which is why so often her crimes are an effort to aid the natural world.

Ivy is also capable of using plants to spy on her enemies, thanks to her ability to both hear and speak through plant life. She cannot have children, but has previously created her own “sporelings”. Ivy’s power is so immense that at one point she actually controlled the entire population. That’s quite impressive for a character created to be little more than a pretty face to distract Batman.
The Floronic Man

Now, let’s discuss the guy who’s responsible for Pamela Isley’s transformation into Poison Ivy. Jason Woodrue was created by Gardner Fox and Gil Kane. He made his first appearance in The Atom in 1962, but didn’t debut as the Floronic Man until 1976. Perhaps best known as an enemy of Swamp Thing, he’s also been a thorn in Batman’s side, and to many other heroes as well. Initially called Plant Master, Woodrue was in exile from a world called Floria. He attempted to use his vast knowledge of plant growth in a ridiculous yet diabolical plan to take over the world. Thankfully, the Atom kicked his ass. He later transformed into a plant/human hybrid and began calling himself the Floronic Man.

Woodrue had a rather advanced knowledge of botany that he frequently seemed to think would lead him to world domination. As the Floronic Man, he could both merge with and control plant life. In a rather gross twist, eating the organs of Swamp Thing once enabled him to have dominion over all plants. Consumed by that power, he decided to destroy everything else. Swamp Thing eventually foiled his plan by explaining that plant life couldn’t survive without animals. The guy doesn’t exactly sound like a genius.
Rose and Thorn

Here’s where it gets confusing because there are two characters who went by Rose and Thorn. One was a villain with plant-based abilities and the other was a hero with no superpowers. Just for fun, let’s take a look at both. John Broome and Carmine Infantino created the first, Rose Canton, in 1947. Rose had a split personality and her villainous alter ego, Thorn, could control plants. Thorn began as Rose’s imaginary friend, but thanks to the sap of a tropical plant, she gained these powers, which also for some reason included the ability to rapidly spin like a top. At one point, she was ostensibly cured and married Golden Age Green Lantern, Alan Scott. Sadly, it wasn’t long before her insanity returned. Rose eventually wound up sacrificing herself to keep her family safe from Thorn.

The second Rose and Thorn was dreamed up by Poison Ivy co-creator Robert Kanigher and Ross Andru in 1970. Rhosyn Lynne Forrest was the daughter of a Metropolis police detective who was killed by a gang called the 100. When Rose slept, Thorn would go all vigilante and stalk the gang responsible for her father’s death. After she brought them to justice, Thorn disappeared for a bit. However, once the gang had reformed as, wait for it, the 1000, Thorn was back in action. Unlike the Golden Age version of the character, this iteration of Thorn had no superpowers to speak of. She was highly athletic though and was known to carry thorn-shaped weapons.
Black Orchid

Prepare to get even more confused because there are four characters who went by Black Orchid! Sheldon Mayer and Tony DeZuniga created Susan Linden-Thorne, who can be traced back to 1973. The heroine didn’t have much of an origin, just powers such as flight, strength and the ability to disguise her appearance. Her calling card was a black orchid. The incomparable team of Neil Gaiman and Dave McKean reimagined the character in their 1989 series. Both writer and artist were initially disappointed to be assigned the task of giving Black Orchid a revamp. Thanks to their mutual love of Swamp Thing and Susan’s lack of a background though, they were able to take Black Orchid in a completely different direction. She was now a plant-human hybrid with major ties to the Green.

Basically, Gaiman and McKean killed off the original Black Orchid and introduced her sisters/clones, Suzy and Flora. Also hybrids, they had the same abilities as Susan. They could absorb nutrients from the air and emit seductive pheromones as well. Jeff Lemire and Mikel Janin introduced another Black Orchid named Alba Garcia in 2011. She could manipulate the Green and the Red (it’s like the Green, but with animal life).

Last time we talked about Marvel characters with plant-based powers, so it’s only fair we spend some time on the “Distinguished Competition” as well. Like Marvel’s writers and artists, those working at DC Comics were incredibly imaginative when it came to the origins and powers of their creations.

children.text: Flower Power: 5 Marvel Characters With Plant - Based Abilities

Superheroes get their powers from any number of sources, some far more ridiculous than others. The abilities derived from being bitten by a radioactive spider, exposure to a gamma explosion or an emergency transfusion of mongoose blood - I swear to you that I did not make up that last one - vary greatly from one character to another. Comics would be pretty boring if they didn’t.

Plant-based powers come in many different forms, affecting the characters who have been blessed (or cursed) with them in a myriad of fascinating ways. The following Marvel heroes – we’ll get to DC next time – have all gained abilities rooted in nature. Sorry, no pun intended there. Only one of them is really well known, while the others are a bit more obscure.
Groot

Let’s start with everyone’s favorite Guardian of the Galaxy, Groot. It’s hard to believe that the gentle giant we all know and love started out as a 125-foot tall monster who referred to himself as "overlord of all the timber in the galaxy”. Seriously, the Groot created by Stan Lee, Larry Lieber and Jack Kirby in 1960 wasn’t even remotely heroic. In fact, he basically terrorized the Marvel Universe for decades. However, Groot’s villainous past was basically retconned after it was established that everyone from the sentient tree’s home world shared the same name, meaning those were the actions of a different Groot entirely. Although, the character also later referred to his former attempt at world domination, so thanks to some continuity confusion, the beginning of Groot’s comic journey remains a bit muddled. These days though, he is unequivocally a hero.

Groot’s power set is incredibly impressive. He can stretch his entire body, much in the same way as Reed Richards from the Fantastic Four. Groot is the Dutch word for “large” and he can indeed alter his size. Like the alien plant that he is, Groot also has the vital ability to regenerate. Even if reduced to a twig, he will eventually grow back to his normal size. Groot can also control plant life, bending them to his will, even creating his own army if necessary. Although he only ever utters his trademark sentence, “I am Groot”, it has been established that the character can be saying any number of things when these words are spoken. Despite his seemingly limited vocabulary, a telepathic link with the X-Men’s Jean Grey revealed that he is actually a very intelligent creature. Not everyone speaks Groot, but those closest to him understand every word.
Plantman

Now, moving onto the lesser known, but creatively named Plantman. Seriously, no one strained too many muscles coming up with that superhero moniker. Stan Lee, Jerry Siegel and Dick Ayer created Samuel Smithers, aka Plantman, in 1963. He was an orphan who found work with a well-known botanist. Together, they studied the intelligence of plants. After his mentor’s death, Smithers sought to continue the work that they’d done together. He eventually discovered a way to communicate with plant life, but was laughed out of the scientific community. However, Smithers had the last laugh when lightning struck his ray gun, which he cleverly chose to rechristen the “Vege-ray”. Thus, the supervillain Plantman was born. I mean, some people had laughed at the guy, so it was obviously the only logical course of action.

The Vege-ray gave Smithers the ability to both animate and control plants. He also managed to create simuloids, which were basically plants that were capable of looking like people. They even possessed limited artificial intelligence, which enabled Samuel’s escape from the authorities on more than one occasion. He simply duped the cops with plant facsimiles of himself. In fact, Smithers has gone so far as to create an entire army of simuloids to do his evil bidding. Although his powers were initially based on whatever equipment he had invented, his body eventually mutated thanks to years of exposure to his own weapons. He then took on the name “Blackheath”. Hey, it’s marginally better than Plantman.
Klara Prast

Created by Joss Whedon and Michael Ryan for Runaways, Klara Prast is a more recent addition on this list. She made her comics debut in 2007. Although physiologically a mutant, Klara’s kind were called “Wonders” in the time period that she was from. Her life in early 1900s New York City wasn’t exactly awesome. Scared by her powers, Klara’s devoutly religious mother married her off to a much older (and meaner) man. She caught the attention of the Runaways - who thankfully, had traveled back in time - after using her abilities to escape a sweatshop fire. It took Klara some time to warm up to the team, but eventually she hitched a ride with them back to modern times. It certainly wasn’t always clear skies with the Runaways, but Klara had found a family that truly accepted her. She chose the superhero codename “Rose Red”, but her teammate Molly much preferred “Tower of Flower”.

Klara Prast’s name is actually a play on chloroplast, which is found in green plant cells. Her main powers are Botanopathy and Chlorokinesis. Botanopathy enables her to communicate with plant life. Roses, in particular, can actually speak back to her, hence the name Rose Red. As for Chlorokinesis, she can control plants in both growth and movement. Despite her affinity for roses, she can actually do this with all plants. She can use vegetation both offensively and defensively, but needs to focus in order to do so. If panicked, Klara’s abilities can spin out of control. Imagine having to keep your emotions in check so that you don’t accidentally attack your friends with plants. And I thought I had problems!
Nature Girl

Like Klara Prast, Lin Li, aka Nature Girl, is a mutant. She is also another character without too much history in the comics. Lin Li was created by Jason Latour and Mahmud Asrar in 2014. Like most X-Men-in-training, she attended the Jean Grey School for Higher Learning (formerly Xavier's School for Gifted Youngsters). Lin is a taciturn girl who prefers the company of various creatures to most humans. No judgment there. After witnessing her abilities, fellow classmate Eye-Boy gave her the codename “Nature Girl”. Lin didn’t oppose the moniker, but mostly, that was probably because she didn’t say much of anything at all that day. She later joined Generation X, a team of mutants who chose to attempt to find a sense of normalcy, despite their powers, rather than becoming full-fledged heroes. Considering the penchant that the X-Men have for dying, this seems an understandable decision.

Lin’s power set is extremely cool, because she has ties to both plants and animals. She has control over all aspects of the natural world, including the weather and even Earth’s geology. Lin doesn’t particularly enjoy talking to people, but she’s excellent at communicating with animals. Whether they’re the everyday variety or demonic creatures, Nature Girl can not only speak to them, but also have a calming effect. Like several other characters on this list, she also has the power of botanopathy. She even has the ability to heal nature. For such a cool character, Lin has been pretty underused since her introduction. Hopefully, someone will eventually remedy that. Nature Girl for life!
Man - Thing

You may recognize Man-Thing from the 2005 movie of the same name. You might not though, since hardly anyone saw it. Stan Lee, Roy Thomas, Gerry Conway and Gray Morrow created Dr. Theodore “Ted” Sallis in 1971. He bears a striking resemblance to DC’s Swamp Thing and although the two publishing companies argued about the similarities between these characters, the matter was never brought to court. Both heroes debuted in 1971. Although Marvel technically beat DC to the punch, Swamp Thing and Man-Thing undoubtedly owe a debt to the Heap, a Hillman Periodicals character who dates back to 1942. This is surely the reason that no lawsuit was ever filed. As for Ted, he was a scientist involved in yet another program designed to recreate the Super-Soldier Serum that birthed Captain America. Side note: when will people learn that’s a horrible idea? After his wife betrayed him to the villainous A.I.M., they attempted to steal his work. Ted injected himself with the serum to keep it out of their hands. However, he also wound up crashing into the swamp and Man-Thing was born.

Whether or not Man-Thing retained any sentience after his transformation depends on which comics you read. Generally though, it’s accepted that he’s not sentient, but incredibly empathetic. Man-Thing exists at the Nexus of All Realities, which means that he has access to many other worlds from his area of the Everglades. He’s pretty much indestructible, because if anything happens to his body, it will simply regrow. If the character had a catchphrase, it would be, "Whatever knows fear burns at the Man-Thing's touch!” This basically means that his body secretes a chemical that will burn anyone who is feeling fair. To be fair, who’s not freaking out when being touched by a gigantic swamp monster? It seems to be a bit of an unfair system.

Plant-based powers come in many different forms, affecting the characters who have been blessed (or cursed) with them in a myriad of fascinating ways. The following Marvel heroes – we’ll get to DC next time – have all gained abilities rooted in nature.

children.text: Tyrannosaurus rex: The Tyrant Lizard King

When it comes to Dinosaurs, the first one that pops into people’s minds is Tyrannosaurus rex. T.rex has been a huge part of pop culture, it has appeared in movies, television, video games, etc. But what if I told you that the T.rex that you’ve seen in Jurassic Park is nothing like its real-life counterpart? In reality, T.rex was a large muscular and powerful animal, that wasn’t built for chasing after jeeps driven by Jeff Goldblum. In this article I will be covering the T.rexes ecosystem, it’s physiology, and theorized hunting methods.

Tyrannosaurus rex roamed the earth in the late Cretaceous about 70-66 million years ago in the Hell Creek formation which went through Montana, North and South Dakota, and Wyoming. The Hell Creek ecosystem consisted of semi-arid plains, inland and coastal subtropical areas, and was overall a warm and humid climate. It was such a diverse ecosystem that included a variety of animals such as dinosaurs, pterosaurs, mammals, reptiles, and insects. Examples of the dinosaurs T.rex lived alongside with are Pachycephalosaurus, Triceratops, Dakotaraptor, and Ankylosaurus. In Hell Creek, T.rex was the dominant apex predator that feared nothing except its own species.

The physiology of Tyrannosaurus is what makes it one of my favorite dinosaurs of all time, it was 40 feet in length and was 15 to 20 feet tall. It weighed anywhere from 18, 518 to 30,864 pounds, making it one of the largest theropods in mass (Yes, Spinosaurus were larger but only in size). Its body was most likely covered in scales as an adult while juveniles and possibly young sub-adults were covered in feathers and lost them as they got older. T.rex reached full size in less than 20 years and increased its size by about 1,500 pounds per year meaning it spent 90% of its life eating. Its skull was around 5 feet in length with forward-facing eyes, giving it binocular vision similar to us! This binocular vision gave it great depth-perception which allowed it to judge how far away prey was. Tyrannosaurus had large powerful jaws filled with 60 thick, conical and serrated 9-inch teeth that enabled it to crush bones with ease. These jaws gave T.rex the strongest bite force in the entire animal kingdom, an adult Tyrannosaurus could have exerted 7,869 to 12,814 pounds of force (35,000-57,000 Newtons). It also had strong muscular legs, a long muscular tail used for balance and the most well-known feature was its small muscular arms which were 3 feet in length. Contrary to belief, evidence suggests that T.rex did, in fact, use its arms as specimens have been found with signs of torn muscles on their arms. But how did T.rex use its arms? Well, theories suggest that it may have been used to help restrain prey once said prey has been bitten. For example, say a T.rex is hunting a Triceratops, Tyrannosaurus would have bitten down on the Trike preferably on the neck and then would have used its arms to grab the Trike while it tries to crush the Triceratops’s neck with its powerful jaws. Overall Tyrannosaurus is the perfect example of a living tank, it was able to take down tough prey thanks to its physiology and is arguably one of the most successful and powerful theropod dinosaurs.
Life-Size replica of what T.rex may have looked like:

While T.rex was certainly a powerful and efficient predator, some paleontologists in the field believe T.rex was a strict scavenger due to it being slow; estimated speeds being between 10 to 25 mph but it could only run at these speeds for a short period of time due to it taking a lot of energy for something that big to move so fast. I, on the other hand, believe Tyrannosaurus was an opportunistic predator. As with most predators in the animal kingdom, they will seize the opportunity for a free meal if recent hunts have ended in failure of catching prey and will also hunt if it needs to.

There is fossil evidence that points toward Tyrannosaurus being an active hunter, both evidence comes from one of its favorite prey: Edmontosaurus. Edmontosaurus was a large hadrosaur or as people know them: duck-billed dinosaurs. Two Edmontosaur specimens have been found with evidence of being attacked by a Tyrannosaurus and both had survived the encounter due to signs of healing being found on the bones. But with it being slow how was it able to catch fast prey such as Edmontosaurus? Well, T.rex most likely relied on ambushing its prey, waiting to get close then striking. So in this scenario let’s picture a herd of Edmontosaurus grazing in a lightly forested field and hiding in the trees is a Tyrannosaurus rex. The T.rex would slowly move towards them while keeping an eye out for an older member of the herd since they would be easier to catch, unlike a young adult. As it is moving towards the herd one Edmontosaur makes the mistake of turning its back to the trees, this is when the T.rex strikes and as soon as the Edmontosaur turns its head back the T.rex is already charging at it. Before the Edmontosaurus starts to run the T.rex bites down on its neck and using its own weight it slams the unlucky Edmontosaurus to the ground and crushes its neck. T.rex would need to take down prey as fast as possible in order to reduce the risk of injury. But sometimes injury is inevitable and is caused by your own species.

Each T.rex found has some sort of injury, mostly caused by another Tyrannosaurus. One of the most fascinating injuries is a Tyrannosaurus that had part of its tail bitten off, this specimen is known as Wyrex. As mentioned before; T.rex needed its tail for balance and the muscles that T.rex used to walk were connected to the tail. The fact that Wyrex was able to survive with half of its tail missing brings into question how this missing portion of the tail affected the way it walked post-injury. But how and why did these violent interactions come to be? Well, it might be anything from territorial disputes, food disputes, or battles over mating rights. All these injuries show that T.rex was very active and was a violent animal. To sum this all up, T.rex was a very successful predator and completely dominated its diverse ecosystem. Their physiology was perfectly built for its environment and it used its weight to its own advantage and was able to efficiently take down prey. When it comes to dinosaurs, T.rex lived up to its name and was truly a Tyrant Lizard King.
In the next Paleo-Profile, I will be covering the largest dinosaur ever discovered: The Argentinosaurus!

“‘…We have no future. Not in the sense that our grandparents had a future, or thought they did. Fully imagined cultural futures were the luxury of another day, one in which, ‘now’ was of some greater duration. For us, of course, things can change so abruptly, so violently, so profoundly, that futures like our grandparents' have insufficient ‘now’ to stand on. We have no future because our present is too volatile” […] ‘We have only risk management. The spinning of the given moments’ scenarios. Pattern Recognition.’”
--William Gibson, Pattern Recognition (2003)
For Lack of a Future…
I like hippies and I like hackers. I like both very much. For a while it seemed paradoxical. And then I began searching. What I found surprised me.

I landed on the Wikipedia page of Timothy Leary. He gave us the 1960s counterculture slogan: “Turn on, Tune in, Drop out." He was called the most dangerous man of the 1960s by Richard Nixon. He advocated for psychedelics and ecstatically embraced technology. He went to prison and was in a solitary confinement cell beside Charles Manson. His friends the Weathermen, and Leary updated turn on, tune in drop out later as “Turn on, Boot up, Jack in” (Wikipedia.org. Cyberdelic). He was also quoted as calling the PC “the LSD of the 1990s” (Cyberdelic). No, he’s not without sin or flaw but, if there is anyone who understood where the future was leading, it was Leary.

What do we do with Gibson’s (2003) assessment of our “too volatile” present? We can choose to agree or disagree. In spite of its eloquent wording, I disagree with the sentiment. I can see the logic. In 2003 the world as we knew it was just going into a very extreme stage of cultural flux. All the visions of the future seemed to enter into combat. So many competing notions that nobody knew what to do with them. Sixteen years later it’s not much clearer.

Our ‘fully imagined cultural’ future does seem to be a foggy notion. We are not the first generation in history to weather this uncertainty. When will our present give us time to dream like our grandparents? It won’t.

We have to own the responsibility ourselves and shift into that meditation by our own free will. In the real world, nothing is given. Nothing is owed. Somethings are stolen, others are earned. Regardless, initiative is taken on some level. A choice is made. Choice is at the center of life.

I had some downtime after I twisted my knee running trails in the park. Found myself DVRing Keanu Reeves movies and reading in my much-needed downtime. I’d been in a pattern that led to injury, it was a cycle—a pattern. Then, the injury happened. And I had a choice to continue or alter the cycle. I changed it and I healed. Time is a healer if we take proper care.
Now is our chance to create a new pattern.
Questions We Need to Ask
“The Lassans had experimented with most vices; but planned obsolescence and conspicuous consumption were not among them.”
--Arthur Clarke, Songs of Distant Earth (1986)

Shouldn’t we all be living more hedonistic, fulfilling, and loving lives by now? What went wrong? How do we fix it? How do we find our way? How do we fall back into true love with each other? How do we un-become that which we don’t want to be?
Traveling has always been a dream of mine. I want to see more of my world. There is a hiccup, I want my travels to not contribute to the death of the sights I want to see.

Do we have to give up any dreams of world travel? I read a New York Times article that said international and long-distance travel burns enough fossil fuels and expedites the melting of the northern wonders like glaciers and Icecaps. Racing to see them, makes them melt faster.

I think it’s possible to find more environmentally friendly means of transportation. A life without travel, without the experience of new cultures is an insular one. Isolationism isn’t ideologically healthy. It breeds fear-based thinking: nationalism, racism, xenophobia. These are products of ignorance born from isolation. So, what would a cleaner, greener version of the present look like?

In allowing my imagination to run, an idea hit me. The future I see is a little bit old and a little bit modern. Somewhat Amish, somewhat cosmopolitan. Can you imagine what a horse and carriage with modern shock absorption technology would feel like? Silly question? Maybe not. You walk or ride (horse or bicycle, or carriage) to a bus or train station, take an energy-efficient bus or train burning some as of not yet known substance that does significantly less damage to the air if any at all, as it takes you from Seattle to Chicago or Miami to New York. Maybe a sea voyage, on a passenger company from New York to London. Imagine the Titanic without steam power (or the sinking).

Cities with rooftop gardens and edible landscapes. Our lifestyles are changing every day. Who’s to say this can’t work? Snail mail and email coexist, as do text and instant messaging Life is quaint in some places, we’ve got state parks and wildlands plenty to roam. Surely somehow someone finds a way to blemish it. That’s okay because we’ll cope. There's no reality without a bit of good and bad alike. It’s a civilization. Maybe it’s a democracy, anarchy, or monarchy.

Why can’t we have a world that is practically identical to what is and was, in its infrastructure and operation? Why must “what will be” be so bleak? Yes, we have deforested, we have wasted and continue to waste precious non-renewable resources. As it is, we have to find alternative energy sources. There is no argument.

All of the above is common knowledge to me and I hope to many more of you out there reading this. But in any contest, a cooler head prevails. Business as usual economy is on its way out. But it’s not taking my world down with it. Any attempt to do so will be met with the full force of my own belligerent resistance.

How do we get here? Cooperation. Arthur Clarke’s Songs of Distant Earth, (1986) imagines a civilization beyond what we commonly known. I’d live there. Science fiction precedes science fact in most cases. Arthur C. Clarke’s 3 laws that come to mind:
They are:
1. When a distinguished but elderly scientist states that something is possible, he is almost certainly right. When he states that something is impossible, he is very probably wrong.
2. The only way of discovering the limits of the possible is to venture a little way past them into the impossible.
3. Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.
(Wikipedia.org. Clarke’s Three Laws.)
As long as we dispense with complacent thinking there is nothing we can’t do. We’ll reach a point in history when old merges with new in a stunningly smooth way.
I encourage you to speculate with hope rather than fear. Even though we have obstacles in our way, there is always hope. It’s the one thing Pandora left trapped inside the box.

Woodstock that place where “half a million kids learned they were part of a larger organism” (Wiki, Woodstock) was a point of no return. The hippies saw the light, set the flame, just gotta keep it burning.
The climate changes but we have our feet in the virtual as well as the actual. It’s a strange time to be alive.

children.text: “There are believed to be 46,000 pieces of plastic in every square mile of ocean," (oceancrusaders.org). As a child, I was always drawn towards the sea. Deep blue water lapping at the shore. Rushing in and out with sparkling white foamy edges. A blanket for shells and sea glass. Little did I know that just beyond Ariel's childhood home neighboring Atlantis floated the Kingdom of Plastic; The Great Pacific Garbage patch. A place where sea turtles mistake plastic bags for their favorite meal... the jellyfish.
"Plastic pollution does not only impact sea life, it also carries toxic pollutants into the food chain – a food chain including us humans," (TheOceanCleanup.com).

Plastic has become a big problem. A problem that some have tried to curtail. Viral videos are swimming around of surfers pulling garbage from the waves, DIY tutorials on how to repurpose straws for hanging terrariums, and even footage of resourceful nine-year-old, Ryan Hickman, who started his very own recycling company in California.

It's uplifting to know that there are so many people out there who care about the planet and the life it sustains. However, it simply isn't enough to halt the ongoing issue. Dutch inventor and entrepreneur, Boyan Slat, knew this and at eighteen years old decided it was time to take a stand by devising "a concept which utilizes the natural oceanic forces to passively catch and concentrate ocean plastic, through which the theoretical cleanup time could be reduced from millennia to mere years," (boyanslat.com).
So whether you're into turtles, mermaids, or simply enjoy living on our slowly dying planet, let's keep it clean people.

Rebirth and Renewal: A New Spring Begins

Spring is here. It’s definitely here. What is spring about? I could tell you everything you’re already expecting to happen. Those of you with a decade or two behind you already, you know what comes: the re-greening of the leaves and the petals and colors coming out. I see the people who might have hibernated in the winter re-emerging from their homes. I am unconvinced that there is a soul alive which doesn’t find a reason or two to get out under the sun.

This morning I ran. It was warm enough, so I peeled off a layer—my sweater—I wrapped it around my waist. I ran hard. Dancing through the trees and over the roots on the trails—never in a straight line for long. I ran my wiggly way through the woods. Building up heat quickly, I peeled my base layer off my chest and tucked it in my cargo pocket. My wool hat pulled down over my warm head, bare chest huffing out and in taking the crisp gentle breeze of this fifty-plus degree day. My skin comes alive at the touch of the wind. These new sensations not felt since last year’s warmth. This day didn’t scorch, dampen, or brown my skin. Instead it invigorated me like a shot of adrenaline to the heart.

Others out in the park were bundled in winter vests, jackets, and hats. I won’t disparage their choices. I am not superior. I have my own deficiencies and they are mine to know and divulge. I simply tolerate different conditions in funnier ways than some. We all adapt differently. This is my call to you: Do what you have to. Adapt yourself to the season. Weather is less predictable than ever before with the changing climate. I promise you this: things will get weirder before they get better. Maybe the weirdness is the solution. So, if you can accept the diversity of choices at our disposal, then you are on your way toward striving to better yourself and your world.

Now I’m back at the park after a few errands, more heavily dressed. I am lying in the middle of a grassy knoll warmed by the sun. I see the cloudless blue above when I opened my eyes. The grass below and around me wiggles. The branches of the trees near me creak as they bend. Everybody in sight is moving. Walking, jogging, or pedaling a bicycle. Even the air isn’t still. Warm winds blow in chilly. My right sinus is a little dry and achy from the morning. I trust the discomfort to subside soon. Desiccated brown leaves that survived the winter blow on the gusts. They are destined for degradation. Their branches will welcome the new growth. I—always the non-conformist-- am still. With legs crossed and my journal on one knee, I observe like a lion waked from a nap. My pages flutter with increasing aggression. I too should be moving on. Stillness is for later, after nightfall. The sun is still high.

Ducks are drinking from a stream as I walk over a footbridge. The lake is alive again. The bike path is closed. I pick my way down a jagged slope of rocks, tread briefly on the bike path and I move along and find another scene at the jetty by the lake. I see a girl wearing earbuds, wrestling with the fluttering pages of her spiral bound notebook. An old man sits by the water on a bench. He is wearing earbuds. I greet another man with a wave and pass. He too is wearing earbuds. This modern touch does little to spoil the serenity. The smell of the lake blows by me. I hear its waves lap the shore.

There are long shadows now as I leave this modern, living Norman Rockwell scene and make my way to where I parked. I will come back and maybe make a habit this spring of taking time to recline as I did today. I will run again. I will keep adventuring.
We have risen from our winter slumber. It is time to gather our strength and rise to the challenge of the journey ahead.
Andrew Cosma writes about the ambiance of a park in early spring.

children.text: Origins of Halloween
Halloween is the time when the wolves howl, the witches are witchy, the goblins gobble and we go for a trick and a treat, but who celebrated it before we did and what was it like?

The origins of Halloween date back to Samhain (pronounced sow-in), an ancient Celtic festival. They celebrated the New Year on November 1st which marked the end of summer, the harvest, and also the beginning of the dark, cold winter. This time of year usually had something to do with death.
The Celtic people believed that on the night before the New Year the worlds between the living and dead became blurred.
On October 31st they celebrated Samhain and were certain that the dead returned to earth.

Celtics believed that the presence of spirits made it easier for the Druids to make predictions about the future. The Druids made giant sacred bonfires whereupon they would burn crops and animals as sacrifices... During their celebrations, the Celts would wear costumes and try to tell each other's fortunes.

When the Roman Empire had conquered Celtic territory, two Roman festivals were combined with Samhain. The first was Feralia, in late October when the Romans commemorated the passing of the dead. The second was a day to honor the Roman goddess of fruit and trees, Pomona. The symbol for Pomona is the apple which probably explains the tradition of "bobbing" for apples and maybe even caramel apples.

As Christianity spread through Celtic lands, it blended with Celtic practices. The church made November 2nd, a day to honor the dead, All Souls' Day. It is believed that the church tried to replace the Celtic festival of the dead with a related, but church-sanctioned holiday. All Souls Day was celebrated similarly to Samhain, it included big bonfires, parades, and dressing up in costumes. This day was also called All-hallows, All-Hallowmas or Alholowmess. The night before was soon called All-hallows Eve. Then finally, Mischief Night and Halloween were born.

The celebration of Halloween was quite limited in New England. Europeans and American Indians made a similar American version of Halloween. The first celebrations included parties and events where neighbors would tell stories about the dead and each other's fortunes. Colonial Halloween festivities featured ghost stories and making mischief.

America was flooded with new immigrants, especially the Irish who helped to popularize Halloween. From Irish and English traditions, Americans began to dress up in costumes and go house to house asking for food, this eventually became "trick-or-treat." Young women thought that on Halloween they could find the name or appearance of their future husband by doing tricks with yarn, apples, and mirrors. Trick-or-treating probably dates back to the All Souls' Day parades in England. During the festivals, the poor would beg for food and families would give them "soul cakes." In return, they would pray for the family's dead relatives. Giving out soul cakes was then encouraged by the church as a way to replace the practice of leaving food for roaming spirits. This tradition of children visiting houses in their neighborhood and being given, food or money became known as "going a-souling."

Dressing in costume for Halloween has European and Celtic roots. Hundreds of years ago, winter was an eery time since food usually ran low and on Halloween people thought they might encounter spirits if they left their homes. To avoid being recognized by them people wore masks when they left their homes after dark so that the ghosts would mistake them for spirits. And to keep ghosts away on Halloween, people would place bowls of food outside to prevent them from trying to come in.

Halloween has always been a time filled with mystery, magic, and superstition. It began as the end-of-summer festival during which people felt especially close to their deceased relatives and friends. For these friendly spirits, they set places at the dinner table, left treats on doorsteps and lit candles to help them find their way back to the spirit world. Today's ghosts are depicted as fearsome and violent. And the superstitions that follow are scarier too. One of which explains why we avoid black cats, for fear that they will bring bad luck. In the middle ages, many people believed that witches avoided detection by turning into cats.

Every year around the time of Halloween, we try to avoid breaking mirrors, stepping on cracks or spilling salt. But when the wolves stop howling, the witches aren’t wicked, goblins don’t gobble and we stop trick or treating it’s just another plain old day. So enjoy your Halloween and see ya next year...

"Personally, I would be delighted if there were a life after death, especially if it permitted me to continue to learn about this world and others, if it gave me a chance to discover how history turns out." -- Carl Sagan
